issues.title: 4.4 --- Attesting Environment
issues.author: mcr
issues.body:
If a TPM is the Attesting environment, then in the case where this system had a TPM, this statement would not be true, no?
In other words, shouldn’t this example be restricted to attestation without a TPM?  (I think you can say something like “hardware root of trust for verification” or something if we should avoid naming technologies)

In contrast, I think in a TPM system, the firmware initializes the Attesting Environment, the TPM is the attesting environment, and the same attesting environment is used by all layers.

comments.author: dthaler
comments.body:
For context, Guy's comment was on the first sentence in this paragraph:

> After the boot sequence is started, the BIOS conducts the most
>    important and defining feature of layered attestation, which is that
>    the successfully measured Target Environment B now becomes (or
>    contains) an Attesting Environment for the next layer.  This
>    procedure in Layered Attestation is sometimes called "staging".  It
>    is important that the new Attesting Environment B not be able to
>    alter any Claims about its own Target Environment B.  This can be
>    ensured having those Claims be either signed by Attesting Environment
>    A or stored in an untamperable manner by Attesting Environment A.

My understanding is that a TPM requires another entity to feed it measurements which the TPM measures, the TPM doesn't actively collect claims itself.  Thus to me, the TPM is not the Attesting Environment.  The Attesting Environment is the _combination of the TPM + whatever is feeding it the measurements_.   Viewed that way, I believe the text is true as written.

comments.author: henkbirkholz
comments.body: Yes. We need text that captures that prominently and then also in that text start with "the composite of TPM & root of trust for measurement" forms an Attesting Environment instead of "he TPM is not the Attesting Environment". Starting with the latter seems to produce reflexive and unnecessary knee-jerk reactions that we can also easily resolve, finally. Does that sound like a feasible approach?

comments.author: dthaler
comments.body:
> Yes. We need text that captures that prominently and then also in that text start with "the composite of TPM & root of trust for measurement" forms an Attesting Environment instead of "he TPM is not the Attesting Environment". Starting with the latter seems to produce reflexive and unnecessary knee-jerk reactions that we can also easily resolve, finally. Does that sound like a feasible approach?

Yes I like that.

comments.author: mcr
comments.body:
section: ## Two Types of Environments of an Attester
now includes text:

~~~~
There is no limit to or requirement on the types of hardware or software environments that can be used to implement an Attesting Environment, for example: Trusted Execution Environments (TEEs), embedded Secure Elements
(eSEs), Trusted Platform Modules (TPMs), or BIOS firmware.
An arbitrary execution environment may not, by default, be capable of claims collection for a given Target Environment.
Execution environments that are designed specifically to be capable of claims collection are referred to in this document as Attesting Environments.
~~~~

comments.author: William-PanWei
comments.body:
> Another comment I have on this section is about the trust model of a composite device: it looks like the lead attester needs to be trusted to collect the most fresh evidence from the other slots? Is this discussed anywhere?

Who do you mean the lead Attester needs to be trusted by? The Verifier/Relying Party or other slots/Attesters?
The collecting capability is one of the characteristics the lead Attester has. So after the Verifier verifies the Evidence of the lead Attester successfully, it can trust the lead Attester's collecting capability.
The Evidence of other slots are signed by these slots themselves, and these slots can send Evidence to the lead Attester just as the lead Attester sends Evidence to the on-path router to the Verifier.

comments.author: thomas-fossati
comments.body:
> Who do you mean the lead Attester needs to be trusted by? The Verifier/Relying Party or other slots/Attesters?

I meant the latter - apologies for the lack of precision.  In particular, I am interested in the scenario where a compromised lead that has cached some previously collected evidences, can forward those instead of fresh slots' attestations.

Plumbing aside, it’s the verifier that collects and analyses the evidence, generating a Result to send to the Relying Party, isn’t it?

If we really are comparing with the Background Check procedure, I think the relying party (the employer) usually contracts an agency (the verifier) to collect evidence from the attester (the prospective employee), i.e., the relying party does not act as a pass-through, and may not be allowed to see all the evidence anyway.

For example, in a medical insurance claim scenario, the insurance applicant (Attester) submits an invoice (Evidence) issued by the hospital to the insurance company (RP), and the insurance company (RP) sends the invoice to the hospital (Verifier) to verify its authenticity.

comments.author: dthaler
comments.body:
My opinion is this one is just an email response, no change to text:

1. The industry already has multiple formats today.   Multiple is important, expanding the set indefinitely is not intended or good, but if someone (like another SDO) does add another one, RATS can accommodate it.
2. "should [attack surface] be compared in all the other variations in this document" -> if there's an important requirement that falls out of it yes.  But I don't know of one.   "how do you know it's even true" -> not sure what "it" refers to but if it is "minimizing code footprint", then it's true that 2 parsers is generally more code than 1 parser (the onus of showing otherwise would be on the person arguing that 2 parsers is less code than 1 parser).   "should this one be deleted" -> no.

issues.title: 7.2 -- Attester
issues.author: mcr
issues.body:
````
In some cases where Evidence contains sensitive information, an
   Attester might even require that a Verifier first go through a TLS
   authentication or a remote attestation procedure with it before the
   Attester will send the sensitive Evidence.  _This can be done by
   having the Attester first act as a Verifier/Relying Party, and the
   Verifier act as its own Attester, as discussed above._
````

I don’t know what it means, but all the cases here seem to ultimately rely on a unitary Verifier/Relying-Party somewhere in the chain.

Maybe that’s not true…  if the verifier and relying party trust each other by fiat, the roles need not be combined.

comments.author: dthaler
comments.body:
It means this:  Say you have devices A (normally an Attester) and V (normally a Verifier) and RP (normally a Relying Party).   A can say it won't send Evidence to V unless V first attests to A.   Thus, A starts by acting as a Relying Party where V is the Attester.  If A devices that V is trustworthy, then A can start sending sensitive Evidence to V.

Note this does not require anywhere have a combined Verifier/Relying Party.

comments.author: henkbirkholz
comments.body:
I can see how:
* "Verifier/Relying Party" looks misleading here
* Dave illustrated well that this text is not about a "unitary Verifier/Relying-Party"
* this is related to the current mutual authentication/attestation discussion that recently emerged

I'll try to pitch this issues in the next meeting so we can deal with it in the same swoop as mutual authentication. Personally, I'd simply leave the text as is.

````

How does this, for example, impact RATS?
Does RATS include a way to express all these variations, or is it just saying there are a whole lot of assumptions that can be made in determining what to trust?

comments.author: nedmsmith
comments.body:
My assessment of the entire section 7.4 is that it says very little about what a Verifier is or does. There existing text seems to focus on giving advice about the different aspects of what it means to trust different entities that may be performing the various roles in the attestation architecture. Certainly, the verifier is the most complex of all the roles with 4 inputs and one output message. And we have made an architectural decision to put the complexity in the Verifier generally. It seems to do this in a way that makes it clear, the section should be broken into smaller parts. For example, a sub section for each input / output message type. There are some basic sequence of operations too, such as verifying signature, decoding of messages, discovering and assembling all the context needed before appraisal can start. Then there is appraisal processing. What constitutes a match between Evidence claims and Reference Value claims etc. 

But if the objective of the section is to just talk about what the semantics of 'trust' are, maybe it achieves that goal already. Though it doesn't do a great job of laying out that that is the goal.

comments.author: mcr
comments.body:
Splitting it up into smaller pieces may be reasonable.

But, this is an architecture document: we need to define the inputs and outputs of the Verifier (functional requirements).
We don't need to write design requirements!  

The whole point of hiding all the complexity in the Verifier is so that we can intelligently explain the protocols in/out of it, and drive standardization (commodification) of the Attester.   This is classic CS "add a layer of indirection"
Secondarily, the RP role should become simpler, but as the X diagram implies, the RP also gets to push complexity to the Verifier.  
If the WG is unhappy with this, then I think that the WG should start a document providing a deeper analysis of the Verifier.
This is consistent with #162.

   However, while an appraisal policy that treats all devices from a
   given manufacturer the same may be appropriate for some use cases, it

   compliant devices are considered authorized for some purpose.  For
   example, an enterprise using remote attestation for Network Endpoint
   Assessment may not wish to let every healthy laptop from the same
   manufacturer onto the network, but instead only want to let devices

comments.body:
````
I think what you mean is that proof of identity and attestation of software integrity are (OMG) not the same thing??
````
I don't think so. This paragraph highlights that you may need different appraisal policies for the devices from the same manufacturer or even the same type of devices.
For example, one enterprise may buy some Apple laptops, but it doesn't mean all Apple laptops can access the enterprise network. So an appraisal policy that allows all healthy Apple laptops (having the valid certificated signed by Apple and pass the attestation of software integrity) to access isn't appropriate.

issues.title: 8.3 Attestation Results
issues.author: mcr
issues.body:
````
Attestation Results are the input used by the Relying Party to decide
   the extent to which it will trust a particular Attester, and allow it
   to access some data or perform some operation.  Attestation Results
   may be a Boolean simply indicating compliance or non-compliance with
   a Verifier's appraisal policy, _or a rich set of Claims about the
   Attester, against which the Relying Party applies its Appraisal
   Policy for Attestation Results._
````

In this case, what’s the benefit of designating a Relying Party as separate from a verifier?  The first verifier is digesting evidence to create different evidence to give to the next verifier, which has a built-in implicitly-trusted relying party?

comments.author: nedmsmith
comments.body: The AR Claims likely are different from Evidence Claims. The Verifier determines that the Attester is "Trusted" for some definition of trust. Then maps to a Relying Party specific implication - for example access authorization. An example of a non-binary authorization is an OAuth2 token. If a RATS verifier were integrated into an OAuth2 AS, then the Attestation Result might easily be an OAuth2 token.

comments.author: nedmsmith
comments.body: Won't Fix? - The reasons for separating or combining Verifier and RP roles on the same entity (actor) are dealt with in another section.

comments.author: mcr
comments.body: closed with email in: https://mailarchive.ietf.org/arch/msg/rats/993-8As7beiuLqliXRd3-mb433U

issues.title: 8.3 Attestation Results - authorization
issues.author: mcr
issues.body:
````
he passport model) or a Relying Party (in the background-check
   model) to indicate that the _Attester should not be treated as
   authorized_ and may be in need of remediation.  In some cases, it may
   even indicate that the Evidence itself cannot be authenticated as
   being correct.
````

Is there a different way to say this?  I assume in Passport, we’re not relying on the Attester to report itself as untrustworthy?
I think it’s more that it doesn’t get a passport, so it has nothing to hand the dude at the immigration desk?  i.e. untrustworthiness is indicated by lack of a passport?

comments.author: nedmsmith
comments.body:
The paragraph should begin with "An Attestation Result that indicates ..."
The Relying Party is *always* the entity / role that consumes the Attestation Result. The text that describes the Attester (in the passport model) technically violates the role interaction model. 

Instead, the refusal on behalf of an Attester (acting as a proxy for the Attestation Result) to convey the AR is a protocol or interaction break down scenario. And yes it is correct for the Relying Party to, by default, assume that lack of receipt of an Attestation Result means the Attester is presumed to be non-compliant. 

If the paragraph stated this simply up front then we can avoid dove tailing it into the description of what constitutes non-compliance behavior. For example, paragraph 2 could start differently:
"By default the Relying Party assumes the Attester does not comply with Verifier appraisals. Upon receipt of an authentic Attestation Result and given the Appraisal Policy for Relying Party is satisfied. The Attester's state of compliance changes to be in compliance and actions consistent with compliance may be applied. If the Appraisal Policy for Relying Party is not satisfied, actions consistent with non-compliance may be applied. For example, the Attester may require remediation and re-configuration or simply may be denied further access."

The third paragraph seems redundant to this (and somewhat wordy).

issues.title: 10. Freshness is a key component
issues.author: mcr
issues.body:
````
The goal is merely
   to narrow their recentness to something the Verifier (for Evidence)
   or Relying Party (for Attestation Result) is willing to accept.
   _Freshness is a key component_ for enabling caching and reuse of both
   Evidence and Attestation Results, which is especially valuable in
   cases where their computation uses a substantial part of the resource
   budget (e.g., energy in constrained devices).
````

I think what you mean is that “some flexibility on the requirement for freshness is a key component…”, i.e., it’s the willingness to accept a result that’s been around for a while enables caching.

comments.author: nedmsmith
comments.body: agree.

issues.title: 11. Privacy Considerations, level of assurance
issues.author: mcr
issues.body:
````
Some Attesters might want a stronger level of assurance
   of the trustworthiness of a Verifier before sending Evidence to it.
   In such cases, an Attester can first act as a Relying Party and ask
   for the Verifier's own Attestation Result, and appraising it just as
   a Relying Party would appraise an Attestation Result for any other
   purpose.
````

Is this a description of mutual authentication?  If so, should it use the term?
In this case, how would each side decide what to reveal if it has to attest the other side first?
Seems like, in practice, there’d be some kind of bootstrapping ladder of trust?  i.e., they have to agree on each other’s identity before moving on to attestation results?

You could introduce the TCG Privacy CA idea as a way to solve this deadlock, but I’ll admit I don’t think that approach has many fans these days.

comments.author: nedmsmith
comments.body:
Concur that it appears to be describing 'mutual-attestation'. We should define the concept then use it to describe the privacy consideration. 

The privacy consideration in this paragraph appears to be:
"Evidence may contain privacy sensitive information" 
"Attester is responsible for evaluating whether disclosure of Evidence to a Verifier is safe (from a privacy perspective)"

It is an aside IMO whether or not mutual attestation addresses sufficiently the privacy consequences of disclosure of Evidence. The Verifier might be highly domain isolated and authenticated, but still not behave in a way that protects the privacy interests of the Attester.

issues.title: 12.1 Attester/Attestation Key Protection
issues.author: mcr
issues.body:
````
   Implementers need to pay close attention to the _isolation_ and
   protection of the Attester and the factory processes for provisioning
   the _Attestation Key Material_.  When either of these are compromised,
   the remote attestation becomes worthless because the attacker can
   forge Evidence.
````

What does isolation mean in this context?
Do you need to be explicit about requirements for the keys that go into each device vs the keys used to sign p


Does this include both identity keys and attestation evidence signing keys?

comments.author: nedmsmith
comments.body:
The concept is that the Attester function and the data objects it controls (aka keys) must be domain isolated. Wiki offers a definition for domain https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Domain that includes a software engineering context. This  use of domain is in the context of a 'protection domain' which isn't defined by wiki or IETF. https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/rfc4949/ does define domain / security domain. 

We're saying that a protection domain is a IETF security domain where the properties of protection are known or enumerateable. 

A protection domain has the properties:
- isolation - the Attester (Attesting Environment) can't be observed or tampered with such that the Claims it authorizes can be altered. And the Claims is collects can't be misrepresented by the Target Env.

comments.author: mcr
comments.body:
> The concept is that the Attester function and the data objects it controls (aka keys) must be domain isolated. Wiki offers a definition for domain https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Domain that includes a software engineering context. This use of domain is in the context of a 'protection domain' which isn't defined by wiki or IETF. https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/rfc4949/ does define domain / security domain.

Okay, but I don't know what to do with this.  Do we change anything?

comments.author: mcr
comments.body: In the text, this now says "protection", so I am closing this issue.

issues.title: 12.1.1. On-Device Attester
issues.author: mcr
issues.body:
````
In many cases the user or owner of the device must not be able to
   modify or exfiltrate keys from the Attesting Environment of the
   Attester.  For example the owner or user of a mobile phone or FIDO
   authenticator is not trusted.  The point of remote attestation is for
   the Relying Party to be able to trust the Attester even though they
   don't trust the user or owner.

   Some of the measures for low level security include process or
   application isolation by a high-level operating system, and perhaps
   restricting access to root or system privilege.  For extremely simple
   single-use devices that don't use a protected mode operating system,
   like a Bluetooth speaker, the isolation might only be the plastic
   housing for the device.
````

1) This wording implies that there are other cases where it’s acceptable to exfiltrate or modify keys.  Do those still count as Attestation?

I know RATS must be ‘inclusive’, but is it meant to include absolutely everything?  For example:

  If I had a router with the following features:
A root password
A serial number in a file owned by root
TLS
A shell script that computes the hash of the kernel and stores it in a file on startup
A Show command that prints the serial number, software version string, date and the hash.
  …  would I have a RATS-Compliant Attestation System?
It provides evidence
The evidence is protected by encryption (TLS)
There are a zillion different formats for evidence, so I assume ASCII strings count
The Attesting Environment is protected by the root password
Freshness is assured by the date, which in turn is protected by the root password.

2) The example goes on to say that this statement is not true; you don’t need process isolation.

3) What does a plastic case have to do with attestation?

4)

comments.author: nedmsmith
comments.body:
The last three paragraphs have to be taken together as they're describing three hardening levels ('low'. 'medium', 'high'). I don't believe the goal of the security considerations is to define hardening levels. If so, it should be in a different part of the document. The preceding paragraph - "In many cases the user or owner of the device must not be able to modify or exfiltrate keys from the Attesting Environment of the Attester.  For example the owner or user of a mobile phone or FIDO  authenticator is not trusted.  The point of remote attestation is for the Relying Party to be able to trust the Attester even though they don't trust the user or owner." - introduces the concept that the Attester's domain isolation can have multiple levels of hardening. It would be cleaner to capture this idea as the security consideration.

e.g. "The Attester's domain isolation technique may have differing protection properties that rely on different hardening strategies. These differences can be accounted for by including endorsement Claims that describes protection properties and hardening strategy applied to the Attester".  

Some examples may follow if that makes sense where the examples already provided seems to be:
- FIDO
- Process / app isolation (aka memory ring protections)
- physical housing
- TEE
- side channel attack mitigations

issues.title: 12.1.1  - HIgh Level Security
issues.author: mcr
issues.body:
````
 For high level security, specialized hardware will likely be used
   providing protection against chip decapping attacks, power supply and
   clock glitching, faulting injection and RF and power side channel
   attacks.
````

This section, as put, is kind of a big leap, no?
I think the important part of this next level, is the introduction of a hardware root of trust like a TPM to *eliminate* the need to trust the device’s operating system software in reporting attestation results.

comments.author: laurencelundblade
comments.body:
@laurencelundblade 

How about "For strongest security,...." to avoid confusion with high level OS.

comments.author: mcr
comments.body: This also already fixed by existing text #272.

issues.title: 12.1.2 Attestation Key Provisioning Process
issues.author: mcr
issues.body:
It seems that all that’s relevant to RATS is “if the key is generated externally, the manufacturer needs to take care to protect it with measures consistent with its value”

````
   Another way to provision the key material is to generate it on the
   device and export the verification key.  If public key cryptography
   is being used, then only integrity
````
This case does seem different – there is simply no known way to extract the key.

comments.author: nedmsmith
comments.body:
I agree with MCR's summary that “if the key is generated externally, the manufacturer needs to take care to protect it with measures consistent with its value”. Can we replace the bulk of section 12.1.2 with this single sentence? 
The expectation is that private keys can't be extracted (read) once provisioned. That should be a stated security assumption.  This section reads like a tutorial or primer. That isn't the goal IMO. Security Considerations should state our our security assumptions.

comments.author: mcr
comments.body: {not my comment. Guy's.  If you like that part, generate a pull request please!}

issues.title: 12.2 Integrity Protection
issues.author: mcr
issues.body:
````
It is also important that the appraisal policy was itself obtained
   securely.  As such, if appraisal policies for a Relying Party or for
   a Verifier can be configured _via a network protocol_, the ability to
   create Evidence about the integrity of the entity
````

Does this mean to imply that bogus policy can’t be installed by sneakernet, e.g., on a usb thumb drive??

comments.author: nedmsmith
comments.body: I don't think the 'via a network protocol' is necessary. The consideration is simply that policies have security considerations that are out of scope of the architecture.

issues.title: 12.1 --- Integrity at different layers
issues.author: mcr
issues.body:
````
   The security of conveyed information may be applied at different
   layers, whether by a conveyance protocol, or an information encoding
   format.  This architecture expects attestation messages (i.e.,
   Evidence, Attestation Results, Endorsements and Policies) are end-to-
   end protected based on the role interaction context.  For example, if
   an Attester produces Evidence that is relayed through some other
````

The first sentence seems to say ‘you can do whatever you want’, but the second seems to say “you should sign the messages”

This doesn’t seem to be about integrity; it says Evidence must be confidential.  Is that actually a requirement?

comments.author: nedmsmith
comments.body:
I don't see where it says RATS messages have to be confidential. 
'end-to-end' means between RATS roles. Which can be achieved at different nesting levels; where nesting is interpreted to mean nesting in the message (data) layers. 
Summary - I don't see a problem with the proposed text.

comments.author: henkbirkholz
comments.body:
I am inclined to agree with Ned here, but we could change the first line, while we're at it.

> The security protecting conveyed information may be applied at different

The reuse of the word "protected" used in the 1st sentence in the 2nd sentence

> This architecture expects attestation messages (i.e.,Evidence, Attestation Results, Endorsements and Policies) are end-to-end protected

now might make it more clear that this message protection can happen on many layers.

issues.title: 12.1.1 first paragraph
issues.author: nedmsmith
issues.body:
"It is assumed that the Attester is located in an isolated environment of a device like a process, a dedicated chip a TEE or such that collects the Claims, formats them and signs them with an Attestation Key."

The grammar seems off to me. Should be:
"It is assumed that the Attester is located in an isolated environment of a device such as; 
     * a process, 
     * a dedicated chip, 
     * a TEE,
     * a virtual machine,
     * a secure mode of operation
or other forms of domain isolation that allows collection of Claims from the target environment where the target environment cannot lie or interfere with the claims collection function.
Additionally, the Attester formats collected Claims and integrity protects them with an Attestation Key that also is domain isolated such that the target environment or some other entity other than the Attester is not able to undermine the Attester's protections"

issues.title: 16.1. Example 1, troubles with the third paragraph
issues.author: thomas-fossati
issues.body:
Section "16.1. Example 1", third para:
```
If time(VG_a) is also included in the Evidence along
with the claim value generated at that time, and the
Verifier decides that it can trust the time(VG_a) value,
the Verifier can also determine whether the claim value
is recent by checking time(RG_v) - time(VG_a) < Threshold,
again where the threshold is large enough to account for
the maximum permitted clock skew between the Verifier
and the Attester.
```
I find the reference to clock skew slightly confusing.

The Threshold value here is more likely to depend on a verification policy
that defines what is an acceptable "age" of the sampled claim rather than
on considerations about clocks drifting.

issues.title: abstract inconsistency
issues.author: thomas-fossati
issues.body:
The last sentence of the abstract is:
```
This document describes an architecture for such remote attestation
procedures (RATS).
```
but _"such" remote attestation procedures_ are not defined earlier.

issues.title: Section 3.6 Hardware Watchdog is confusing
issues.author: thomas-fossati
issues.body:
There seems to be some confusion: initially it is said that the _"Relying Party is the watchdog timer in the TPM."_
Subsequently, the Relying Party is defined as _"A remote server that will securely grant the Attester [...]"_.
So, what is it?

comments.author: henkbirkholz
comments.body:
For context, this is now: https://ietf-rats-wg.github.io/architecture/draft-ietf-rats-architecture.html#name-hardware-watchdog

This is plainly wrong (probably due being left over as an artifact after revising the text). How about:

"Relying Party: The watchdog capable to trigger a procedure that resets a device into a remediatable operational state."

comments.author: thomas-fossati
comments.body: WFM, except I am not sure "remediatable" is a word.  You want to use "known, good" instead?

comments.author: henkbirkholz
comments.body: Sry for my native language habit of concatenating and mangling existing terms. "Known, good" reads very appropriate. Thanks!

issues.title: obscure paragraph  "Layered Attestation Environments" section
issues.author: thomas-fossati
issues.body:
I don't understand what this para is supposed to communicate:
```
   By definition, the Attester role creates Evidence.  An Attester may
   consist of one or more nested or staged environments, adding
   complexity to the architectural structure.  The unifying component is
   the root of trust and the nested, staged, or chained attestation
   Evidence produced.  The nested or chained structure includes Claims,
   collected by the Attester to aid in the assurance or believability of
   the attestation Evidence.
```

Also, pick one of "nested", "staged" or "chained" and drop the rest.

comments.author: henkbirkholz
comments.body:
For context: this is now https://ietf-rats-wg.github.io/architecture/draft-ietf-rats-architecture.html#section-3.4
"Layered Attestation Environments"

How about this as a new starting point:

> By definition, the Attester role generates Evidence.
> An Attester may consist of one or more nested environments (layers).
> The root layers of Attesters are called roots of trust.
> A root of trust can generate Evidence, but never about itself.
> A root of trust must be endorsed from the outside.
> A root of trust in consequence can be the initial Attesting Environment in layered attestation.
> Claims can be collected from or about each layer, including roots of trust.
> The corresponding claims can be structured in a nested fashion that reflects the nesting of the Attester's layers.

Effectively, I removed the last sentence, as I had a hard time to understand what it intended to add to the content here. My proposal is intended as a rework of this paragraph that goes beyond editorial changes. The current last sentence still seems a bit out of place to me.

comments.author: thomas-fossati
comments.body: Looks very good as a starting point.  Thanks!

comments.author: dthaler
comments.body:
> How about this as a new starting point:
> 
> > By definition, the Attester role generates Evidence.
> > An Attester may consist of one or more nested environments (layers).
> > The root layers of Attesters are called roots of trust.

All good so far.

> > A root of trust can generate Evidence, but never about itself.

This sentence can be confusing, since I think it could include claims about itself in Evidence, as admitted in your point below ("Claims can be collected from or about each layer, including roots of trust.")

> > A root of trust must be endorsed from the outside.

Disagree with "must be endorsed".   Either the verifier has to trust the root of trust itself (e.g., put the root of trust's public key into its trust anchor store directly) OR must be endorsed (e.g., put the endorser's public key into the verifier's trust anchor store).

> > A root of trust in consequence can be the initial Attesting Environment in layered attestation.
> > Claims can be collected from or about each layer, including roots of trust.
> > The corresponding claims can be structured in a nested fashion that reflects the nesting of the Attester's layers.

Fine.

issues.title: reduce verbosity in Section 5
issues.author: thomas-fossati
issues.body:
The three sentences _"There are multiple [...]"_, _"This section includes [...]"_ and _"This is not intended [...]"_ are slightly vague.  It doesn't seem to me that their information content is enough to justify them being independent sentences.
They should probably be combined.

comments.author: henkbirkholz
comments.body:
OLD:

> Figure 1 shows a basic model for communication between an Attester, a Verifier, and a Relying Party. The Attester conveys its Evidence to the Verifier for appraisal, and the Relying Party gets the Attestation Result from the Verifier. There are multiple other possible models. This section includes some reference models. This is not intended to be a restrictive list, and other variations may exist.

NEW:

> Figure 1 shows a basic model for communication between an Attester, a Verifier, and a Relying Party. The Attester conveys its Evidence to the Verifier for appraisal, and the Relying Party gets the Attestation Result from the Verifier. This section introduces and names two reference models and their combined hybrid to illustrate typical variations of the basic model and to demonstrate the composability of roles defined in this document.

comments.author: thomas-fossati
comments.body:
(slight refinement)

_"Figure 1 shows an abstract model for communication between an Attester, a Verifier, and a Relying Party. The Attester conveys its Evidence to the Verifier for appraisal, and the Relying Party gets the Attestation Result from the Verifier. This section refines it by describing two reference interaction schemes (topological models), as well as one possible compositions thereof.  The discussion that follows is for illustrative purposes only and does not constrain the interactions between RATS roles to the presented patterns."_

comments.author: henkbirkholz
comments.body: Reads good to me. Any other comments? (starting a virtual going once...)

issues.title: Two comments on the "Passport Model" section
issues.author: thomas-fossati
issues.body:
1. Should this section have a forward ref to the freshness section (or otherwise discuss the freshness of the attestation results)?

2. I think that if we'd drop the paragraph below, no important information would be lost (I may be missing something but they all look like implementation details to me):
```
   There are three ways in which the process may fail.  First, the
   Verifier may refuse to issue the Attestation Result due to some error
   in processing, or some missing input to the Verifier.  The second way
   in which the process may fail is when the Attestation Result is
   examined by the Relying Party, and based upon the appraisal policy,
   the result does not pass the policy.  The third way is when the
   Verifier is unreachable.
```

comments.author: henkbirkholz
comments.body:
1.) In general, all three models here have sightly varyin  freshness characteristics. I am uncertain that this is the place to discuss them. This question is similar to the lack of consistent use of freshness related terms that recently came up. Will investigate more.

2.) pulled in Dave by assigning him to this issue as I think that text was written by him. The answer here depends on scoping content for the model descriptions, too.

comments.author: dthaler
comments.body: This text is actually from @mcr who added it as part of https://github.com/ietf-rats-wg/architecture/issues/37

comments.author: dthaler
comments.body:
On question 2, I would keep it since the point was to address issue 37.
On question 1, I think it's a subcase of the first way (verifier rejects because evidence isn't fresh) and a subcase of the second way (RP rejects because attestation results aren't fresh), it's not a fourth way per se.  I'd be fine with either
a) adding freshness (and a forward reference) into the "or"s of the first way, or
b) making the wording of the first way more like the wording the second way.

That is, (a)

>   There are three ways in which the process may fail.  First, the
>    Verifier may refuse to issue the Attestation Result due to some error
>    in processing, or the Evidence not being fresh (see {{freshness}}), or some missing input to the Verifier.  The second way
>    in which the process may fail is when the Attestation Result is
>    examined by the Relying Party, and based upon the appraisal policy,
>    the result does not pass the policy.  The third way is when the
>    Verifier is unreachable.

or (b)

>   There are three ways in which the process may fail.  First, the
>    Verifier may refuse to issue the Attestation Result due to the Evidence
>    not passing the Appraisal Policy for Evidence.  The second way
>    in which the process may fail is when the Attestation Result is
>    examined by the Relying Party, and based upon the Appraisal Policy for Attestation Results,
>    the result does not pass the policy.  The third way is when the
>    Verifier is unreachable.

The latter, (b), is my preference.

issues.title: redundant text in the "Background Check" section
issues.author: thomas-fossati
issues.body:
The paragraph:
```
   Hence, the ability to let the Relying Party obtain an Attestation
   Result [...]
```
seems to reshuffle the content of the preceding one.  The two can be combined / streamlined.

comments.author: thomas-fossati
comments.body:
Maybe:

_"However, like in the Passport model, an Attestation Result is still consumed by the Relying Party and so the ability to convey it in the same serialization format as the Evidence allows minimizing the code footprint and attack surface area, which is especially  important if the Relying Party is a constrained node."_

comments.author: henkbirkholz
comments.body: Personally, I like the new content here that elaborates on motivation and intent. Anyone else like to chime in here to have in impact on that expositional text?

comments.author: dthaler
comments.body:
The meaning of
> _"However, like in the Passport model, an Attestation Result is still consumed by the Relying Party and so the ability to convey it in the same serialization format as the Evidence allows minimizing the code footprint and attack surface area, which is especially important if the Relying Party is a constrained node."_
is wrong, i.e., format same as the Evidence.   Instead the meaning is format same as the resource access protocol natively uses.

issues.title: possible imprecision in the "Combinations" section
issues.author: thomas-fossati
issues.body:
We say:
```
   It is also worth pointing out that the choice of model is generally
   up to the Relying Party
```

I'm not sure it "is up to the RP"_.  Maybe better saying it "depends on the RP application" (or similar) because it's typically not a choice of the RP but of the use case / protocol flow in which the RP operates...

comments.author: laurencelundblade
comments.body: Proposal: "Individual applications, use cases or protocol flows interacting with the same Attester can use different models."

issues.title: slight cognitive dissonance in the "Roles and Entities" section
issues.author: thomas-fossati
issues.body:
This sentence:
```
   An entity in the RATS architecture includes at least one of the roles
   defined in this document.
```
creates a bit of cognitive dissonance.

In the Terminology section, the Endorser, Ref-val Provider, RP Owner and Verifier Owner are defined as "entities", however, they don't include any of the roles (Verifier, RP, Attester).

comments.author: henkbirkholz
comments.body:
That is a weirdly persistent bug that we have to squash once and for all.

Attester, Verifier, Endorser, RVP, RP, RP Owner, and Verifier Owner are all **roles**. Roles are instantiated by **entities**, which is the term we now use under the premisethat the well-established and understood term principal is to hard to understand for a reader (sry, got a bit rant'y here).

I think I added all the changes that fixes this issue to a PR that was abandoned at the end. It seems we missed to rescue my corresponding changes from that PR, though. Can anybody provide a pointer to these changes? Otherwise we have to dig that up in the next meeting.

issues.title: the "Claims Encoding Formats" back-story needs some work
issues.author: thomas-fossati
issues.body:
This sentence:
```
   To enable remote attestation to be added to existing protocols,
   enabling a higher level of assurance against malware for example, it
   is important that information needed for appraising the Attester be
   usable with existing protocols that have constraints around what
   formats they can transport.
```
it's quite hard to digest.

But more generally, the motivating use case (OPC UA) is slightly convoluted, and I'm wondering whether it is really needed?  But assuming it were, the exposition needs to be improved to present a clear and compelling case.

comments.author: henkbirkholz
comments.body:
I cannot speak for the applicability of OPC UA here. It seems to be an item in an already long list. I actually wonder more why EAP is not in there to add some diversity.

Having said that, how about:

> To enable remote attestation to be added to existing protocols, conceptual messages have to be added to the information already conveyed, sometimes in the encodings already used. The addition of RATS conceptional messages has to be realized in a way that retains their security properties. As an example, if DER-encoded X.509v3 certificates are the only message format used in a protocol, it might become necessary to embed all RATS conceptional messages in the certificates conveyed or even use the same DER-encoding the certificates are represented in.

comments.author: thomas-fossati
comments.body:
Looks much better, thanks!  Elaborating a bit further:

_"Retrofitting already deployed protocols with remote attestation requires adding RATS conceptual messages to the existing data flows.  This must be done in a way that doesn't degrade the security properties of the protocol and should use the native extension mechanisms (if available).  For example, if an authentication protocol (e.g., the TLS handshake) has to be extended with remote attestation capabilities, attestation Evidence may be embedded in an ad-hoc X.509 certificate extension, or into a new TLS Certificate Type."_

comments.author: henkbirkholz
comments.body: You had me at "retro". In my kickstarting proposal, I barged on with "DER", which is now gone but now there are TLS and Certificate Type for elaboration. None, one, or all? I don't want to overload that paragraph with arbitrary examples. Unfortunately, now these start to seem arbitrary to me. What is the reasoning for choosing examples here, actually?

comments.author: thomas-fossati
comments.body:
> Unfortunately, now these start to seem arbitrary to me. What is the reasoning for choosing examples here, actually?

These are both existing mechanisms: the first (new cert extension) is [DICE](https://trustedcomputinggroup.org/wp-content/uploads/DICE-Certificate-Profiles-r01_3june2020-1.pdf), the second (new TLS cert type) is [TLS-CWT](https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/draft-tschofenig-tls-cwt/).   I dropped DER as it's a necessity when using x.509 certs, and looked redundant.

comments.author: henkbirkholz
comments.body: That actually helped me a lot! Maybe we should pull these reference in? I am aware that it is sometimes better to shy away from specifica, but in this case I think it would help the reader to be more specific. Thoughts?

comments.author: thomas-fossati
comments.body: Doing a background check on OP CUA, I've found that the [sec model spec](https://opcfoundation.org/developer-tools/specifications-unified-architecture/part-2-security-model/) is not open, and that there are only two research papers that talk about adding attestation to the existing model: ["Portable Trust Anchor for OPC UA Using Auto-Configuration"](https://ieeexplore.ieee.org/abstract/document/9211904) (2020) and ["Introducing remote attestation and hardware-based cryptography to OPC UA"](https://ieeexplore.ieee.org/document/8247591) (2017).  This paucity of related content makes its presence as a "demo" use case a bit brittle.  I suggest we remove it.  DICE and TLS-CWT should be enough.

issues.title: Brendan's feedback about local clock
issues.author: dthaler
issues.body:
At the IETF 110 meeting, Brendan Moran asked why local clocks are a problem since even MCUs have them.
Currently we have text in the doc like...

in the nonce section:
> and might be suitable, for example, in case the Attester does not have
> a reliable clock or time synchronization is otherwise impaired

in the handles section:

> Like the nonce approach, this allows associating a "rough" epoch without
> requiring a reliable clock or time synchronization in order to generate or
> appraise the freshness of Evidence or Attestation Results.

I answered this by saying in the TEE use case for example, attesting the TEE needs a trusted clock, and having a trusted clock is not common.   Brendan suggested clarifying the clock text.

comments.author: mcr
comments.body:
Isn't it synchronized clocks that are the requirement?
When you say "trusted clocks", do you mean, I can trust that they are securely synchronized?
(Or that I can trust that Cesium still has that frequency, and that the laws of physics haven't been altered?)

comments.author: dthaler
comments.body:
I mean a clock for which code outside the TEE cannot tamper with.   Whether it's synchronized or not is not about whether the clock itself is trusted.

If a TEE wants to know how much time has passed since a previous event, and it has to ask the REE, and the REE can lie, then that clock is not trusted by the TEE.

issues.title: Clarifying layered attestation
issues.author: laurencelundblade
issues.body:
This is about the text that describes layered attestation and Figure 3, the one with environments A, B and C.

I think the critical point about layered attestation (if I understand it) is that the remote Verifier must evaluate the evidence for target environment B with a positive result as a precondition to evaluating the evidence for C. This critical point isn't mentioned in the text.

The other possibility is Attesting Environment A is also the Verifier for the evidence from target environment B. There are two roles in the same box, Attester and Verifier. This seems to be implied by the paragraph after Figure 3. The paragraph that starts "Attesting Environment A... has to ensure the integrity of the boot loader (Target Environment B)". However, figure 3 only shows a remote Verifier.

A third possibility is A does ensure integrity of B, but it's not Attestation. It is just typical staged boot that is being described. It is not layered attestation. I think we should distinguish staged boot from local Attestation Verification. It doesn't seem right to claim that all staged boot is local Attestation Verification and thus RATS applies to all staged boot.

In the cases where A does locally ensure the integrity of B either via staged boot or a local Verifier, then the remote verifier can actually trust the evidence about C without first evaluating the evidence from B.

Or, all three of the above could be intended. There is nothing wrong with implementations that do any of these or combinations of them.

I think the text should decide which of the three it is going after here and be clear about them.

comments.author: PenglinYang
comments.body: Agreed，trust relations between different layers should be clarified. It seems that the concept of trust chain could be used to describe this trust and attestation relations in different layers.

comments.author: dthaler
comments.body:
I think the intent of the text is the first approach, i.e., the one for which Laurence says:

> I think the critical point about layered attestation (if I understand it) is that the remote Verifier must evaluate the evidence for target environment B with a positive result as a precondition to evaluating the evidence for C. This critical point isn't mentioned in the text.

comments.author: PenglinYang
comments.body: In the first approach, if A is the BIOS (root of trust ?), and B is the bootloader, I'm not sure if bootloader has the ability to communicate with remote verifier via network or other methods.

comments.author: dthaler
comments.body: Typically the evidence is provided to some service or application running in or on top of the kernel, that can send the evidence to the verifier or relying party.

comments.author: PenglinYang
comments.body: I understand and agree with your opinion. But that means the fiuge 3 may be inaccurate. The arrow mark orignated from B and pointed to verifier may mislead readers.  And the integrity and confidentiality of evidence also need to be protected carefully.  : )

issues.title: please clarify "security" around handles^Wepoch identifiers
issues.author: mcr
issues.body:
1. I don't think that they need to be confidential, and I'm pretty sure we can't do the group key management to make this work.
2. I can see how it would be nice if they came with origin authentication, which might imply integrity as well. (Usually hard to split this up).  I think that without a better handle (pun intended) on the target use case audience, it's hard to know if one can really make this work.  Clearly an epoch identity distributor  (which would be... a _historian_?) could sign with an asymmetric key, and for some use cases the authenticator (public key) could be widely distributed, or baked into firmware.

To me, the primary security for the identifiers is availability.
I think that the epoch identifier is key to doing the TUDA: if one wants one way attestations coming *out* only of a nuclear power plant, then the freshness has to get in via some broadcast system, I think.

issues.title: Conceptual Messages scoping contradiction
issues.author: dthaler
issues.body:
Figure 1 (Conceptual Data Flow) has the following lines:
* Endorsements
* Reference Values
* Appraisal Policy for Evidence
* Appraisal Policy for Attestation Results
* Evidence
* Attestation Results

All of the above are conceptual messages, though only the last 2 are in scope for RATS to standardize per the current charter.

Appraisal Policies and Reference Values currently have subsections under section 3 (Architectural Overview)., whereas Endorsements, Evidence, and Attestation Results have subsections under section 8 (Conceptual Messages).

The contradiction is that section 8 is titled Conceptual Messages but does not scope itself to either (a) all lines in Figure 1, or (b) the lines in scope for standardization, and as such is inconsistent.

To fix, I think we either need to move Reference Values and the Appraisal Policies down to section 8, or else move Endorsements up to section 3.  (Or repeat some things twice, but I would not want that.)

comments.author: mcr
comments.body:
Lots of support to moving Evidence to section 3.
Other solutions also considered.

comments.author: nedmsmith
comments.body:
Upon review of the arch overview sections for Appraisal Policies and Reference Values sections, I think these sections should be moved to the Conceptual Messages section. But with some modification. Both sections contain a description of the message AND a description of what a conceptual message is (why we're calling it 'conceptual').

E.g. "Reference Values used in appraisal procedures come from a Reference Value Provider and are then used by the appraisal policy." describes a Reference Values conceptual message.  
While "The actual data format and semantics of any Reference Values are specific to Claims and implementations. This architecture document does not define any general purpose format for Reference Values or general means for comparison." describes the properties of a conceptual message. I've rewritten it below substituting 'conceptual message' to make the statement covering of the other messages.
"The actual data format and semantics of any conceptual message are specific to Claims and implementations. This architecture document does not define any general purpose format for conceptual messages or general means for comparison."

Under the "Appraisal Policies" section the following:
"The actual data format and semantics of any Appraisal Policy is implementation specific."
is pretty close to describing properties of any conceptual message.
E.g.:
"The actual data format and semantics of any conceptual message is implementation specific or defined by Internet RFC".

I propose moving the slightly modified sentences above to a new section 8 (8.0) to describe what we mean by conceptual message. 
Move the remaining text and headings in the arch overview for "Appraisal Policy" and "Reference Values" to section 8 as new sub heading 8.4 and 8.5 (or some reasonable ordering of the sections).

issues.title: Section 10 Claims and their values
issues.author: nedmsmith
issues.body: Section 10 first paragraph has the phrase "Claims and their values "; which is redundant. "Claims" is sufficient.

issues.title: Section 12.2 freshness and replay attack
issues.author: nedmsmith
issues.body:
Section 12.2 says "Section 10 discusses ways in which freshness can be used in this architecture to protect against replay attacks." However, the definition of nonce sent (NS) in appendix A says "A nonce not predictable to an Attester (recentness & uniqueness) is sent to an Attester." 

Reply attack is thwarted by 'recentness' and 'uniqueness' according to a protocol's use of 'nonce'. 

Freshness is defined in terms of the Attester's operational state. It is possible to have 'fresh' operational state and still be compromised by a replay attacker. It is also possible to have stale operational state but resist replay attacks due to the senders nonce being processed. 

The fix is to change 'freshness' in the second sentence in section 12.2 to 'recentness'.

comments.author: mcr
comments.body: no consensus to make this change, closing issue.

issues.title: Layering example
issues.author: nedmsmith
issues.body:
I think the text “the read-only BIOS in this example,  has to ensure the integrity of the bootloader” is wrong since the example no longer has a “read-only BIOS” component. 

It should say “ROM” to be consistent. 

If ROM is determined to be ambiguous as a Root of Trust  and we decide to changed it to "RoT" then this sentence would be updated accordingly.

issues.title: Ambiguous attester description in 2.7
issues.author: nicopal
issues.body:
The current attester description in §2.7 is ambiguous and inconsistent with the earlier ones.
Right now it reads:  "Attester:  Every FIDO Authenticator contains an Attester."

To clarify and align the attested description with the earlier ones, I suggest replacing this text with:
"Attester component contained in a FIDO authenticator".

comments.author: nedmsmith
comments.body: Both definitions seem OK to me. The goal of the use cases isn't to provide a technical decomposition of the FIDO device IMHO. Rather, it is to provide a cursory level mapping to the abstract roles / role messages. In fact, if a change is needed I would simply have it say "Attester: FIDO Authenticator".

comments.author: nicopal
comments.body: I agree that a technical decomposition is not the goal, however the current formulation just differs too much from the other ones. The change you suggested - "Attested: FIDO Authenticator" - is a good alternative.

comments.author: mcr
comments.body: "Attester: A FIDO Authenticator".

issues.title: align endorsement definitions
issues.author: thomas-fossati
issues.body:
In §4.2 Endorsement is defined as: _"A secure statement that an Endorser vouches for the integrity of an Attester's various capabilities such as Claims collection and Evidence signing."_

§8.2 uses a more restrictive description: _"An Endorsement is a secure statement that some entity (e.g., a manufacturer) vouches for the integrity of the device's signing capability."_, which seems to limit the scope of an Endorsement to the verification of the Attester's signature on Evidence.

I think §8.2 should be rephrased to align with §4.2 so to allow Endorsements to be more than just verification keys.

Besides, the definition of Endorser in §4.1: _"[…] Endorsements help Verifiers appraise the authenticity of Evidence"_ could be relaxed to drop the (seemingly) exclusive coupling of Endorsements with authenticity appraisal.

comments.author: nedmsmith
comments.body:
+1
Re: §4.1 the alignment of "Endorsements" with "Evidence" seems overly constraining since Reference Values are expected to match Evidence while Endorsements are not expected to be compared to Evidence. The wording "authenticity of Evidence" is what Endorsements qualify but that is too narrow as it could also appraise other Attesting Environment functionality such as Claims Collection, key generation, signing as well as launching code, transitioning to other environments, storing secrets and there could be more.

comments.author: henkbirkholz
comments.body:
Huh. I checked both sections and... I think you both might be right here. While it's not the intent of Section 8.2, factually it seems to be artificially constraining (by accident?). I have to admit, I did not catch that discrepancy. My initial assessment is that - as we took great care with the "normative anchor" that is Section 4.2 - we did not pay enough attention to align Section 8.2 with that.

Taking into account @thomas-fossati's and @nedmsmith's assessment, I think this is an editorial issue. Could @thomas-fossati  please provide a proposal and @nedmsmith please review that first, so that we can address this issue along the upcoming next review phase. This action depends on this change remaining to be a editorial harmonization (again, which I think it is). If there are any counter indications that this is bordering on normative impact, please highlight so.

comments.author: nedmsmith
comments.body: "In some cases, an Endorsement is a secure statement that some entity (e.g., a manufacturer) vouches for the integrity of the device's signing capability."

issues.title: RD AD foundational issues in section 5
issues.author: mcr
issues.body:
````
** Section 5. There is something foundational I am not following about this section.  The interactions described here do not conform behaviors described in the terminology in Section 4 or the high-level reference architecture of Figure 1.  I'm not sure how to reconcile this discrepancy.  

Minimally, these discrepancies are:

-- Figure 5.  Per Section 4, "Attestation Results" are not supposed to be consumed by the "Attester" and are supposed to come from the Verifier (not the Attester).
````

````
-- Figure 6, Evidence is being provided from the Attester to the Relying Party.  Relying part is providing evidence to the Verifier.

Additional sections in the document, e.g., Section 7.2, make use of this interactions too.

The introductory text states that "[t]he discussion that follows is for illustrative purposes only and does not constrain the interactions between RATS roles to the presented patterns."  I don't follow what is being illustrated in the context of RATS.  What is the takeaway for implementers or designers from this section?

** Section 5.1.
In this model, an Attester conveys Evidence to a Verifier, which
   compares the Evidence against its appraisal policy.  

Should the analogy be connected to the RATS architecture by saying the citizen is the Attester and the Evidence is ID (e.g., birth certificate) needed to present to get the passport issued.

** Section 5.1.  Per the paragraph, "Since the resource access protocol ...", I found this text an unexpected level of detail.  No earlier part of the document had previously discussed the existence of a serialization format or resource access protocol, let alone interoperability issues

** Section 7.1  I got a bit lost in the repeated use of the word trust as a verb, noun and adjective.  It seems like two properties should be described:
-
- (authenticity) Trusting that information came from a expected entity/role

-- (correctness) Having confidence in the veracity of the information being provided (e.g., the processes used by the verifier to process the evidence or compute ).

I'd recommend being clearer on what kind of trust is meant.
````

issues.title: RD AD review: vouching by endorser
issues.author: mcr
issues.body:

** Section 7.4.

   In a typical solution, a Verifier comes to trust an Attester
   indirectly by having an Endorser (such as a manufacturer) vouch for
   the Attester's ability to securely generate Evidence, in which case
   the Endorser's key material is stored in the Verifier's trust anchor
   store.

How does an Endorser "vouch" for something?
````

comments.author: nedmsmith
comments.body: "... vouch for the Attester's ability to securely generate Evidence by asserting endorsement claims regarding the ways in which attestation keys are protected. Consequently, the Endorser's key material is stored in the Verifier's trust anchor store so that Endorsements can be included in the Verifier's appraisal."

comments.author: henkbirkholz

** Section 8.1
   Evidence is appraised by a Verifier to establish
   its relevance, compliance, and timeliness
````
What is meant by having to establish that evidence is relevant? Is the concern that the Attester would provide evidence that is not relevant?  Is than attack or attempt a subterfuge?

comments.author: nedmsmith
comments.body: Relevance can refer to how trustworthiness claims are associated with the Attester (Target and Attesting Environments).  Claims associated with TA (a) may not be relevant to Claims associated with TA (b) if (a) and (b) are parts of a composite device. Conversely, if (a) and (b) are layers in a layered device, trustworthiness in (b) could depend on (a) trustworthiness claims as well as (b) trustworthiness Claims.

comments.body: We are erring on the side of the attester oversharing, and we deal with this issue in the Privacy Considerations.

issues.title: RD AD Attestation Result analogy
issues.author: mcr
issues.body:
````
** Section 8.4.

   Thus, Attestation Results often need to include detailed information
   about the Attester, for use by Relying Parties, much like physical
   passports and drivers licenses include personal information such as
   name and date of birth.  
````
I'm not convinced this analogy is helpful.  Yes, it conveys the need for detailed information but it also immediately suggests Attestation Results might include PII or privacy sensitive identifiers.

comments.author: nedmsmith
comments.body:
I agree that the analogy to physical passports is misleading. The paragraph tries to justify AR as being detailed and privacy sensitive then in the next paragraph tries to describe them as not needing to be too specific;
"Unlike Evidence, which is often very device-
   and vendor-specific, Attestation Results can be vendor-neutral, if
   the Verifier has a way to generate vendor-agnostic information based
   on the appraisal of vendor-specific information in Evidence."

It is sufficient to say that both Evidence and Attestation Results can contain privacy sensitive content. The Attester may rely on the Verifier to obfuscate privacy sensitive Claims that were shared as part of Evidence.

comments.author: henkbirkholz
comments.body: It should be clear that appraising Evidence involves various procedures that are part of the appraisal and that these can be quite resource intensive (like creating a passport), in contrast to Attestation Results that are intended to be easily digestible and universal understood (like using a passport)!

comments.author: mcr

In particular,  Is the WG sure that it needs all of the details of Section 10.3.  Even among all of the Section in 10.*, this stands out. issues.body:
** Section 12.2

   It is also important that the appraisal policy was itself obtained
   securely.  If an attacker can configure appraisal policies for a
   Relying Party or for a Verifier, then integrity of the process is
   compromised.

In addition to reconfiguration, wouldn't the ability to intercept either the appraisal policy for evidence or attestation results potentially provide the attacker insight into defensive mitigations?  This suggests that this policy might need confidentiality protection.

comments.body: Maybe #378 fixed this one along with #375

issues.title: Trust anchor definition too narrow
issues.author: thomas-fossati
issues.body:
Throughout the document the term "trust anchor" is meant in the [RFC6024 sense](https://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc6024.html#section-1.1) to be a public key and associated (meta)data.

This definition does not cover attestation schemes based on symmetric crypto, e.g., [TCG MARS](https://trustedcomputinggroup.org/tcg-launches-initiative-to-develop-worlds-tiniest-tpm/), [Symmetric Identity Based Device Attestation for DICE](https://trustedcomputinggroup.org/wp-content/uploads/TCG_DICE_SymIDAttest_v1_r0p94_pubrev.pdf) and Arm PSA, and should be extended to also cover such cases.

comments.author: nedmsmith
comments.body: Was there specific text that you believe needs to be changed?

comments.author: thomas-fossati
comments.body:
> Was there specific text that you believe needs to be changed?

yes, we identified at least two places: §7.1 and §12.4.

issues.title: Replace 'device' with 'system component'
issues.author: nedmsmith
issues.body:
The word 'device' is used dozens of times throughout the document. However, it often doesn't imply 'device' but rather a component of the device. RFC4949 defines 'system component' as:
system component
1. (I) A collection of system resources that (a) forms a physical
or logical part of the system, (b) has specified functions and
interfaces, and (c) is treated (e.g., by policies or
specifications) as existing independently of other parts of the
system. (See: subsystem.)
2. (O) /ITSEC/ An identifiable and self-contained part of a TOE.
Usage: Component is a relative term because components may be
nested; i.e., one component of a system may be a part of another
component of that system.
Tutorial: Components can be characterized as follows:
- A "physical component" has mass and takes up space.
- A "logical component" is an abstraction used to manage and
coordinate aspects of the physical environment, and typically
represents a set of states or capabilities of the system.

This definition seems appropriate for most of the places where 'device' is used. Alternatively, 'system' could be used if 'system component' would be to narrow.

comments.author: mcr
comments.body:
I think that we struggled a lot to arrive at the compromise of saying "device".
I agree with you that there are composite devices which contain "system components".
But, if we do the direction of using that term, we will lose readers and lose comprehension.
I do not agree with this proposal.
If it is unclear that "device" is a role, then I guess we could add that to the Terminology.

comments.author: nedmsmith
comments.body: If I were to be pedantic about what a device is using capital letter names, it is both, it's an entity (that performs the role). The Architecture is a description while normative drafts are more precise / formal descriptions or definitions. I don't feel strongly about it. But some people seem to feel strongly that device is used too much. Does it make sense to talk about how we use 'device' and refer to 4949 system component as being roughly equivalent?

comments.author: henkbirkholz
comments.body: We could say one time early in the text that we mean "system component" when we mean device, but for the sake of simplicity use device as a representative concept throughout the document.

comments.author: nedmsmith
comments.body: Makes sense.

issues.title: Removing root of trust terminology
issues.author: nedmsmith
issues.body: It makes sense to remove the term 'root of trust' since the document doesn't define it. It might make sense to reference other industry specs that have relevant definitions such as NISTIR 8320A.

comments.author: henkbirkholz
comments.body: @nedmsmith apparently, this taks has no assignees. Do you want to do that?

comments.author: nedmsmith
comments.body: OK, assign it to me.

issues.title: are there any special privacy issues around the nonce claim?
issues.author: mcr
issues.body:
The challenger could inject identifying information into the nonce claim.
Do you need to say something specific about this?

comments.author: dthaler
comments.body: I think this discussion belongs in the document that defines the nonce claim (EAT) not the arch doc per se.  Same for any other specific claims that might have similar issues.

comments.author: gmandyam
comments.body:
>I think this discussion belongs in the document that defines the nonce claim (EAT) not the arch doc per se. Same for any other specific claims that might have similar issues.

I think if a discussion regarding privacy for replay protection mechanisms is required, then all documents that EAT inherits from should address this.  EAT already inherits the jti/cti claims from RFC 7519/8392 respectively.  There is no specific privacy discussion in those documents regarding these claims.  Moreover, the cti/jti claims can be client-originated (potentially internal to entity) and can certainly be used for extraction of PII by bad actors, while a nonce is expected to be verifier-generated (i.e. external to entity).

In short, a privacy discussion should cover all anti-replay mechanisms that are possible with CWT/JWT's, not just the claims introduced in EAT.  In that regards, the EAT document may not be the best place for this discussion.  Nevertheless I have made a first attempt:  see https://github.com/ietf-rats-wg/eat/pull/164.

comments.author: thomas-fossati
comments.body:
> I think this discussion belongs in the document that defines the nonce claim (EAT) not the arch doc per se. Same for any other specific claims that might have similar issues.

The reason I brought the issue here is that the nonce is introduced in [Section 10.2 of the architecture](https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/draft-ietf-rats-architecture#section-10.2) and since all RATS documents are supposed to inherit from here, it sounded like a good place to discuss the point once and let downstream docs reference it as many times as needed.

Another convenient place where the privacy discussion can be factored out could be [Section 7.1 of the interaction models](https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/draft-ietf-rats-reference-interaction-models-05#section-7.1).

BTW, I have raised a related issue [in the DAA repo](https://github.com/ietf-rats-wg/draft-ietf-rats-daa/issues/1).

comments.author: mcr
comments.body: https://github.com/ietf-rats-wg/eat/pull/164/files

comments.author: mcr
comments.body:
Discussion of attack in call:

If a Verifier includes the IP address of the Attester in the nonce used for freshness challenge, encrypted, then it will appear to the Attester and possibly some audit process that no PII was leaked.  However, if the symmetric key used for generated this nonce is later made available to some uber-observer, that they could then pull the PII (IP address) out of the audit trail.

DAA/reference-interaction-model could deal with the scenario where the Attester is suspicious of the Verifier.
Consensus that this does not require changes to the document.

issues.title: RD AD editorial comments
issues.author: mcr
issues.body:
Despite fixes in #357 , Roman asks:

[Roman's comments on -13]

-- Section 4.1.  In the definition of relying party, what does the sentence fragment "Compare /relying party/ in [RFC4949]" mean?
-- Section 4.2.  Per the definition of "Claim", what does "Compare /claim/ in [RFC7519]" mean?
-- Section 4.2.  Per the definition of "Appraisal Policy for Attestation Results", what does "Compare /security policy/ in [RFC4949]" mean?

I continue to hold the position that this language "Compare /xxx/ in RFC####" is not clear.  In the natural language sense, that phrase doesn't parse.  If the semantics are being taken from Section 2.6 of RFC4949, please explain that. However, it seems confusing to explicitly be listing antonyms (which RF4949 suggests is the meaning of the "Compare" notation).  In the case of a claim, is it an antonym -- isn't a claim here in fact similar to the one in Section 2 of RFC7519?

comments.author: mcr
comments.body:
````
[2.6](https://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc4949.html#section-2.6). Cross-References

   Some entries contain a parenthetical remark of the form "(See: X.)",
   where X is a list of other, related terms. Some entries contain a
   remark of the form "(Compare: X)", where X is a list of terms that
   either are antonyms of the entry or differ in some other manner worth
   noting.
````

issues.title: RD AD section 5 - Topological Patterns
issues.author: mcr
issues.body:
related to #358 

There is something foundational I am not following about this section.  The interactions described here do not conform behaviors described in the terminology in Section 4 or the high-level reference architecture of Figure 1.  I'm not sure how to reconcile this discrepancy.  

Minimally, these discrepancies in Figure 5 and 6 are not consistent with the roles defined in Section 4.

[restated here but same feedback on -13]

-- Figure 5.  Shows the Attester consuming Attestation Results

-- Figure 5.  Shows the Attester producing Attestation Results

-- Figure 6: Shows Relying party consuming Evidence

-- Figure 6: Shows the Relying Party producing/passing Evidence

The introductory text states that "[t]he discussion that follows is for illustrative purposes only and does not constrain the interactions between RATS roles to the presented patterns."  I don't follow what is being illustrated in the context of RATS.  What is the takeaway for implementers or designers from this section?

[Author's response] https://github.com/ietf-rats-wg/architecture/issues/358

[Roman's response on -15] The above github comment addressed a few issues from the -13 review, but not this one.

comments.author: mcr
comments.body: Reply by email: "The Attester does not consume the Attestation Result, but might cache it. "

comments.author: nedmsmith
comments.body: The text explains the intent correctly regardless of how the lines are drawn. I can convince myself that it is correct draw the line through the box (or not). The important clarifying point should be that the end-to-end message flow as described in the conceptual architecture is preserved through the various topology models that may exist. Second point is there can be a large variety of topology models (aka hybrids) but none of these hybrids changes the expectation of end-to-end message flow.

comments.author: mcr
comments.body: also #415 helps.

issues.title: RD AD comments on section 10 - Freshness
issues.author: mcr
issues.body:
** Section 10.  

[Roman's comment on -13]

I found the level of detail on this section on freshness out of place and inconsistent with the level of abstraction found in the rest of the test.  In most other section, generic interaction of roles, artifacts, their associated topologies, and high level security properties was noted.  This section delves into specific implementation choices.  In particular, is the WG sure that it needs all of the details of Section 10.3.  Even among all of the Section in 10.*, this stands out. It doesn't seem to provide enough detail to be create interoperability but goes beyond simply introducing the concept.

[Roman's comment on -15] Thanks for the extra paragraph to explain why this section is here.  I will confess that I still don't understand why these details are here and stand by my original comment.  It's much more than I would have expected for an architecture (especially considering the extra material in Section 16/Appendix -- 10 pages/almost 20% of the document is devoted to time issues).  If the WG feels like it needs it, I won't push back.  However, if this is the watermark of the level of detail, let's make sure that there is equal treatment for other security issues too.  See my feedback on Section 12.

comments.author: mcr
comments.body:
"Thank you for not pushing back"

https://mailarchive.ietf.org/arch/msg/rats/kj8EoevLNUa7AHjVvW9DK8E_ZTw/ (Eric on section 16)
https://mailarchive.ietf.org/arch/msg/rats/Qki4OIMaYFXKtMdCUKiuCSkEXhs/  (Thomas on section 10)

issues.title: RD AD comments on Security Considerations
issues.author: mcr
issues.body:
[Roman's comments on -13]
I didn't come away from this section with a strong, consistent understanding of which interactions needs which security properties or what considerations are need for which roles.  Section 12.2 is at least clear on integrity, but it also makes vague allusions to other properties.  

-- Section 12.2  This section lists that there might be a need to support additional security properties and provides list (i.e., E2E encryption, DoS protection, authentication, etc.) .  What actionable guidance should be taken from this text?   How should one reason about those properties?

-- The overall Section 12 seems silent on:

o Endorsers and endorsements?
o Reference values?
o What is the implication of combining roles into a single entity as described in Section 3.4 and 6.  Does this lack of separation present any additional issues?
o Compositional devices per Section 3.3?

[Roman's comment on -15]
I didn't see any discussion on text changes in this section related to these comments.  I saw https://github.com/ietf-rats-wg/architecture/issues/367 which seemed to match this feedback, but the associated pull request seemed to fix an editorial issue.

comments.author: mcr
comments.body:
We need to acknowledge that there is a deep hole (not infinitely deep, but not trivial) where we need to look at integrity of all of the different platforms.  
The way that the compositions are composed is a bit tricky, and the results are sometimes different than other people would naively assume.
Are there references here to other papers that we should include?
