issues.title: producing/consuming... do we need a new term of accepting, passing?
issues.author: mcr
issues.body:
> We think that this could sometimes be the case, but we felt that that the
> diagram would best be adjusted anyway.
> (Yes, we came up with different answers two what are apparently the same
> problem with the diagram)
> 
> https://github.com/ietf-rats-wg/architecture/pull/414/files

Thanks for clarifying.

What I'm getting from this text is that there is "producing" and "consuming" per Section 4. 

 I took those terms to be describing/constraining information flow -- what information can comes and go among the various architectural elements.  

It appears that Section 5 is introducing a new behavior which is "accepting" (receiving but not processing) and "passing" (sending but not processing).  There also appear to be element specific behavior of "caching".

I see no conflict with these four behaviors.  My concern is that these nuances in behavior were not explicitly stated.  They should be.  Furthermore, just as certain architectural elements are defined by what they can produce or consume, I'm wondering if the same is true for the "accepting"/"passing" behavior?

issues.title: deal with deep hole of assumed security properties
issues.author: mcr
issues.body:
> > -- The overall Section 12 seems silent on:
> >
> > o What is the implication of combining roles into a single entity as described in Section 3.4 and 6. Does this lack of separation present any additional issues?

[github said: https://github.com/ietf-rats-wg/architecture/issues/407]
==[ snip ]==
We need to acknowledge that there is a deep hole (not infinitely deep, but not trivial) where we need to look at integrity of all of the different platforms.
The way that the compositions are composed is a bit tricky, and the results are sometimes different than other people would naively assume.
Are there references here to other papers that we should include?
==[ snip ]==

I completely agree, that's why I mentioned it.  Composition is hard and can alter the security assumptions of the individual components and introduce emergent risk.

I don't think it can be solved generically.  However, we do need cautionary text here.  Perhaps:

NEW (roughly)

The RATS architecture allows for an entity to function in multiple roles (Section 6) and for composite devices (Section 3.3).  Implementers need to evaluate their designs to ensure that the assumed security properties of the individual components and roles still holds despite the lack of separation, and that emergent risk is not introduced.  The specifics of this evaluation will depend on the implementation and use case is out of scope for this document.

issues.title: Comments from GenART AD
issues.author: mcr
issues.body:
# GEN AD review of draft-ietf-rats-architecture-21

CC @larseggert

Thanks to Gyan S. Mishra for the General Area Review Team (Gen-ART) review
(https://mailarchive.ietf.org/arch/msg/gen-art/weBLFxmD2doRWhcZDm-kGjv8m0A).

## Comments

### Boilerplate

This document uses the RFC2119 keyword ['SHOULD'], but does not contain the
recommended RFC8174 boilerplate.

I don't think you need to add the boilerplate, simply rephrase the sentence
so it is more clear that you are in fact citing RFC4086 here?

### Inclusive language

Found terminology that should be reviewed for inclusivity; see
https://www.rfc-editor.org/part2/#inclusive_language for background and more
guidance:

 * Terms `native` and `natively`; alternatives might be `built-in`,
   `fundamental`, `ingrained`, `intrinsic`, `original`

## Nits

All comments below are about very minor potential issues that you may choose to
address in some way - or ignore - as you see fit. Some were flagged by
automated tools (via https://github.com/larseggert/ietf-reviewtool), so there
will likely be some false positives. There is no need to let me know what you
did with these suggestions.

### Grammar/style

#### Section 2.6, paragraph 2
```
uthenticator. Relying Party: Any web site, mobile application back-end, or s
                                 ^^^^^^^^
```
Nowadays, it's more common to write this as one word.

#### Section 3, paragraph 2
```
em component, device is often used as a illustrative synonym throughout this
                                      ^
```
Use "an" instead of "a" if the following word starts with a vowel sound, e.g.
"an article", "an hour".

#### Section 3, paragraph 4
```
l messages shown in Figure 1. Section Section 4 provides a more complete def
                              ^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^
```
Possible typo: you repeated a word.

#### Section 3.2, paragraph 4
```
-entity can be called an Attester. Among all the Attesters, there may be onl
                                   ^^^^^
```
Do not mix variants of the same word ("among" and "amongst") within a single
text. (Also elsewhere.)

#### Section 3.2, paragraph 5
```
 final Evidence to the Verifier. Therefore the router is a composite device,
                                 ^^^^^^^^^
```
A comma may be missing after the conjunctive/linking adverb "Therefore".

#### Section 3.2, paragraph 6
```
t that connects to the Verifier. Typically one router in the group is design
                                 ^^^^^^^^^
```
A comma may be missing after the conjunctive/linking adverb "Typically".

#### Section 4.1, paragraph 9
```
ation (e.g., birth certificate) is the the Evidence, the passport is an Attes
                                   ^^^^^^^
```
Possible typo: you repeated a word.

#### Section 5.2, paragraph 7
```
e Verifier is an expected one by out of band establishment of key material, c
                                 ^^^^^^^^^^^
```
Did you mean "out-of-band"?

#### Section 7.4, paragraph 1
```
e 1 illustrates the flow of a conceptual messages between various roles. This
                            ^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^
```
The plural noun "messages" cannot be used with the article "a". Did you mean "a
conceptual message" or "conceptual messages"?

#### Section 7.5, paragraph 1
```
n Attester, which can include privacy sensitive information as discussed in s
                              ^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^
```
This word is normally spelled with a hyphen.

#### Section 7.5, paragraph 2
```
ve information as discussed in section Section 11. Unlike Evidence, which is
                               ^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^
```
Possible typo: you repeated a word.

#### Section 9, paragraph 10
```
 new epoch, such as by using a counter signed by the Epoch ID Distributor as
                               ^^^^^^^^^^^^^^
```
This word is normally spelled as one word.

#### Section 9, paragraph 10
```
essages that might be associated with a epoch ID that the receiver has not ye
                                      ^
```
Use "an" instead of "a" if the following word starts with a vowel sound, e.g.
"an article", "an hour".

#### Section 9, paragraph 11
```
 ID approach minimizes the state kept to be independent of the number of Att
                                 ^^^^^^^^^^
```
The verb "kept" is used with the gerund form.

#### Section 11, paragraph 7
```
avoid attacks where an attacker is able get a key they control endorsed. To s
                                   ^^^^^^^^
```
The preposition "to" is required before the verb "get".

#### Section 11, paragraph 8
```
 authentication, * auditing, * fine grained access controls, and * logging. S
                               ^^^^^^^^^^^^
```
This word is normally spelled with a hyphen.

#### Section 12.1.1, paragraph 1
```
pants in a certain epoch of choice for ever, effectively freezing time. This
                                   ^^^^^^^^
```
The adverb "forever" is spelled as one word.

```
station Result contains an expiry time time(RX_v) then it could explicitly ch
                                  ^^^^^^^^^
```
Possible typo: you repeated a word.

#### Section 16.2, paragraph 20
```
 it to its own clock or timestamps. Thus we use a suffix ("a" for Attester, "
                                    ^^^^
```
A comma may be missing after the conjunctive/linking adverb "Thus".

#### "Appendix A.", paragraph 3
```
me(EG_a)-time(VG_a) < Threshold. Similarly if, based on an Attestation Resul
                                 ^^^^^^^^^
```
A comma may be missing after the conjunctive/linking adverb "Similarly".

comments.author: nedmsmith
comments.body: The revised diagram shows support for multiple Results formats excluding TPM. Is there an architectural objective to limit only TPM? It seems the motivation for limiting multiple results formats is to reduce complexity (security objective). However, if the architecture doesn't have this motivation, then filtering TPM formats seems arbitrary. Possibly, the architecture intends to allow multiple Results formats to accommodate protocol constraints. For example, TLS didn't anticipate exchanging Evidence in a handshake, hence it may be necessary to encode it in the certificate path.

comments.author: nedmsmith
comments.body: The Birkholz draft had the idea of roles to describe higher level concepts (independent of transport layer security considerations). It also defined "Actors" that focused on trust model relationships (and their fungibility). Also a higher-layer concept from transport layer security considerations. Each section in the arch spec addresses security considerations appropriate for the level of abstraction. Maybe this security considerations is aimed at transport level security considerations?

Appraisal Policy may come internally or come from a signed policy.  
The Appraisal Policy is a higher-level concept than the concept of Reference Values/Measurements/Known-Good-Values.
Endorsements generally come from the manufacturer only.

Giri: One-Time Integrity Check. The TEE does a run-time (post-boot) check.  I've always viewed this as the job of the Appraisal?  Is that the job of the Endorser? .... 
... no it is the job of the Verifier.  Concluded that this is Local Attestation.
Henk describes situation where all four(three!) roles collapse, and that we might need a new use case described.

comments.body: Who is speaking the Appraisal Policy?
Predominantly, it is the local organization/domain-administrator.  Administrative-Domain. Or Owner.

Does the Known-Good-Value/Reference Value fall into Endorsement or Appraisal Policy? Is it better to add some text into the explanation of the related term to explicitly express that this term includes the Reference Value?

this term gets re-introduced here, without any annotation.
The appraisal policy are the rules on how to test the evidence. 
Here, "Attestation" is the creation of the evidence
Often people use the term "Attestation" to refer to the whole process.
Suggestion that we should define this term *somewhere*, but maybe "Remote Attestation"?
FIDO has NONE-Attestation-Type, where there is no assessment.  TCG would call this Implicit Attestation.  https://www.w3.org/TR/webauthn/#none-attestation
Let's take this to the WG, and maybe we can not get consensus on this term.

Charter says: "Remote
attestation procedures (RATS) enable relying parties to establish a level of
confidence in the trustworthiness of remote system components through the
creation of attestation evidence by remote system components and a processing
chain towards the relying party."
Endorsement is a kind of manifest, like for a ship (a shipper!)

Appraisal Policy! (No, could be both)   Reference Value is a 1:1 comparison.   But, for geo-coordinates it would be more like a policy, a calculation is required.  Appraisal Policy is a super set of Reference Value/KGV. An Endorsement is spoken by a supply chain entity, while an Appraisal Policy is spoken by an Owner.

Appraisal Policy.   And as Michael implies, Reference Value is just an example and is not sufficient in the general case so we do not want to imply that there is necessarily such a thing as a Reference Value, except in a specific example.
Got it. Use Cases draft or 'Use Cases' section is a good place for giving an example to explain that Reference Value is one case of Appraisal Policy.

The diagram changed, but the corresponding text did not? If I remember correctly (did not go through history) there was an optional Verifier role added to the Entity including the "lead Attester" in the previous diagram.

In any case, I think the point was that there could be a local Verifier role on the entity that is also the "lead Attester" (which I assume is the root in a hierarchy of Attesters in a Composite Device). In that role composition the "lead Attester" could create evidence that already includes locally generated Attestation Results with respect to the "rest of the hierarchy of Attesters below the 'root'". What we have to do, I think, is to agree on if and how to include this usage scenario.

As above, this only makes sense, if there would be an optional Verifier role on the entity that is the also the "lead Attester". This "local Verifier" would be the consumer of Appraisal Policies. Again, there is now a lot of inconsistency between text and diagram. We should agree on how to proceed with the "local Verifier" scenario today (if my... deduction is actually correct).

Henk said what I was trying to say. It's my mistake for the missing of the local Verifier role inside the "Lead Attester" in the diagram. My text now is about that the Lead Attester has a Verifier role inside. 

Maybe we can divide the remote attestation for the composite devices into two cases:
1. Lead Attester has no local Verifier role. The Lead Attester just collects the Evidence of other Attesters, then it integrates all these Evidence into one Evidence of the whole composite device (with no or little local processing of the collected Evidence), and it conveys the final Evidence to the Verifier.
2. Lead Attester has a local Verifier role. Then after collecting the Evidence of other attesters, the Lead Attester can verify these Evidence and integrates the verification results into the final Evidence of the whole device. This can help reduce the bandwidth for transporting the Evidence between the device and the Verifier, and also can reduce the load of the Verifier. This may be very helpful when the number of devices is large.
Maybe we can use "Verifying Environment" to refer to the local Verifier role inside the Lead Attester.
The Local Verifier might be a Relying Party for another verifier, it collects the Attestation Results into the Composite Evidence.
We are looking for wording other than "verifying environment (optional)" here.

pulls.title: Add strawman test about freshness
pulls.author: dthaler
pulls.body:
Based on discussion at IETF about including a very high level summary,
and text in the arch docs, draft-birkholz-rats-reference-interaction-model,
and draft-birkholz-rats-tuda.

Signed-off-by: Dave Thaler <dthaler@microsoft.com>

reviews.author: henkbirkholz
reviews.body: A quick review of the strawman, using the strawman to highlight a few points for discussion.

comments.body: Heading the section with freshness and then leading with replay prevention is somehow the other way around, isn't it?
degree of assurance -> level of assurance? Or is this named differently due to a specific intent?

consequently, it would be the latest Evidence and before that the latest Measurement (if we go down the "measure" lane, which I think we do at the moment). Then again, this alliteration of "latest" would look a bit the funny. The point is: what is "nice to know" it is fresh and what "MUST" we know is fresh?

Maybe start with an elaboration of the concept of freshness and that there are "time-windows" or "expiration dates", such as best-before or valid-until.

Please mind that (what the text already implies, I think): Every thing already retrieved is automatically not fresh any more, if it was not _recent_ly retrieved. There can be a tolerance on recentness, which we could define like... "fresh enough". The interval (time-window) is a case-2-case decision, I think.
In this usage scenario the remote entity is also always the challenger/requester of fresh things - not just remote. That would simplify wordsmithing, I think.

"so that the remote entity knows that the claims were signed after the nonce was generated" why is exactly that especially important?

Meandering comment: Nonce are like... "machine TANs"? These can be quite old, but very valid, if appropriately shielded/protected.

Actual comment: How is it ever in question that a nonce is generated after the signing? Is that an implicit description of an attack and preluding content for the security considerations?

Boot-Cycle is a good example I think (but only before the entropy of user-space kicks in. There are other problems regarding the "stability" of these "early boot measurements" today, but that is beside the point here, I think). But still leaves the question open how such a guarantee looks like.

In summary there seem to be four relevant points on time here:

1.) creation of the value in the attestedEE
2.) measurement of the value in the attestingEE to create the Claim value
3.) creation of the evidence
    * with creation of the nonce _before_ the creation of the evidence (although I am still unsure why there is an emphasis on that), or
    * with retrieval of a trustworthy timestamp as close as possible before the creation of the evidence
4.) conveyance/retrieval of the evidence to/by an evidence sink (in general the Verifier or a relaying entity)

Which of these (at least) four points in time are now actually vital wrt to expressing the freshness of the thing conveyed? Maybe this should go into the 2nd item of this section after "an elaboration of the concept of freshness"?
Maybe we change the section title to "Replay Prevention"?
I have no preference.  No specific intent.
(changed section title)
Changed it back and added a sentence into the security considerations section about replay prevention.

comments.body: It seems that the point of this paragraph is that appraisal is a key part of authorization, but often not all.

I am still uncomfortable that in the TEEP case, the term "remediation" is used when "not having TEE thing FOO", is to download and run FOO.  This seems to diminish (trivialises) the meaning of "remediation" to me.  Do we need to define remediation?

I think that a major motivation for the RATS work is to get to vendor-agnostic, even device-agnostic results.  So, not just "This Samsung XYZ phone is safe for HOLLYWOOD1SECURE movies", or even "This smartphone is safe for HOLLYWOOD1SECURE movies", to "This device is HOLLYWOOD1SECURE safe".  I wonder if want to say something more aspiration here.
Who/where are we going to define the containers for these extensions?  Is it the job of RATS?   Does EAT do the work?  Or OPCUA?  Or?

the ,etc. concerns me. I am not opposed to making it open ended, but I'm concerned about being too flexible.
I think that what I'm saying is that if someone wants to encode to a new format, that they would be encouraged to do so as an IETF Action.  That their document would Update: this architecture document perhaps.  Not because they have to, but because it's good to bring them into the tent.  This is an aspiration thought.
what is the relationship to pre-existing vendor formats?  This could be what the "etc" refers to.

pulls.title: Verifier also needs to be trusted by Endorser and Verifier Owner
pulls.author: William-PanWei
pulls.body: For the situation that the Lead Attester has an internal Verifier, the Lead Attester may need to be evaluated first before it receives the Endorsements and Appraisal Policy of other Attesters. This is also a security enhancement.

comments.author: mcr
comments.body: Closed, replaced with #46 after rebase and edits.

reviews.author: mcr
reviews.body: There is some temporal requirements here which I think are reasonable, but we may be putting undo requirements upon the conveyance protocol.

comments.body: This sentence is confusing.  How exactly does it "increase the security" to do things in that order?   And if the other Attesters push their evidence to the lead attester, then the order can't be guaranteed anyway, right?

In the normal Attester case, the Endorser and Verifier Owner needs to trust the Verifier before sending Endorsement and Appraisal Policy to the Verifier. So it is the same in the case that the Lead Attester has an internal Verifier. "increase the security" may not be appropriate, what I want to express is to establish the trust.

The Lead Attester collecting Evidence of other Attesters happens inside the Composite Attester, so I think it doesn't matter when to collect the Evidence.

You said above that the TPM (TEE, HWM) was not available yet, and used the term "eSE", which I don't know. I would have thought the static root-of-trust should have turned that on.  Unless the static root-of-trust has signed the measurement of the UEFI/BIOS/Firmware, how could it be passed forward?

is the meaning of "immutable execution environment" clear enough?   I'm assuming you mean that the code is immutable, but the data is not.

undefined acronyms, e.g., what's HWM?

ROM -> SPL -> UEFI -> ...

You are correct, this is not clear enough. Will be addressed.
Force of habit... willl use "have to"

I assumed we used that already. Did not check. It is a hardware security module, e.g. a S-CRTM (Static Code Root of
Trust for Measurement)
more specific (apparently) but okay

Because I am not sure that every Root of Trust for Measurement does actually sign the measurements. Is that the case? "Shielding" is derived from "shielded location" we should maybe use instead: "A place (memory, register, etc.) where it is safe to operate on sensitive data; data locations that can be accessed only by Protected Capabilities."). Shielded Locations are required to store information, if it is not signed. A can be TEE a shielded location.
Okay
German English... "a bootloader with intact integrity"

eSE is an ARM term, I think. "embedded secure element" It was often referred to with respect to the EAT I-D discussions. We can just say RTM (Root of Trust for Measurement). I am still trying not to include the term trust too often.
Because there is no Root of Trust for Reporting or Attesting Environment  (e.g. a TEE with a TPM) available yet.

I don't think we're using the term "composite attester" now
```suggestion
independent of the concept defined by Composite Devices.
```
Not all FW is BIOS. Not sure BIOS is a good example as it is probably the most complicated of any.
Do we need to provide a detailed example? It may make too many assumptions about terminology and the way things actually work. For example, it can be argued that immutable things are in fact mutable.

I think use of a pantheon of roots-of-trust leads to confusion unnecessarily. We can assert that there is a single 'root' of trust that is the starting point. It can add code into the current or another environment then begin executing it.

We use the term "Attesting environment" now which we presume is "trustworthy". If a "target environment" is going to become a place to execute code, then the "attesting environment" collects claims about the "target environment" that defines its "trustworthiness" properties. 

Maybe it doesn't make sense to relate an example for clarity when the reader may be satisfied with clearly worded architecture text?

I'm confused by the conversation about Composite Device and the unknown thing called Composite Attester in the context of a description of a "Layered Device?" or "Layered Attestation". It seems to me the architecture should clearly describe each independently then let implementation dictate if they should be combined. Combining them shouldn't result in new architecture - not unless there is some anomaly lurking that warrants it.
I think a picture is worth 1000 words. Dave T had an ascii art example that seemed pretty good. Is there a reason not to include it here?

Dave had the ascii art version. Generally speaking it is easier to explain a complex concept by providing a diagram that illustrates the concept. Details about the concept can be organized according to a decomposition of the diagram. If we do this first then examples can be provided for intuition and don't need excessive explanation. We could just say "device bootstrap sequence is an example of a 'layered device' where each phase of boot implements a RATS Attester that collects claims about the next phase".
Maybe there are other use cases that provide intuition - maybe a hypervisor loading a guest VM?

Introduced the term Staging at the end of the 3rd paragraph. I think this is better than not using "staging", it is an intuitive term that does not has to be introduces, necessarily. Any other thoughts?
Could we fix this together please? I find it difficult to make a editorial decision here without further input

relates to the added clarification about ""immutable execution environment". What words are most appropriate here? Static Code Root of Trust for Measurement is very precise and fits the context. But these are also a lot of words and people seem to be easily confused by them.

pulls.author: William-PanWei
pulls.body:
It's more reasonable to say the local Verifier is also a Target Environment.

For the case that Lead Attester has no local Verifier, the Evidence of other Attesters is processed directly by the Attesting Environment. 
For the case that Lead Attester has a local Verifier, the Evidence of other Attesters is verified by the local Verifier (also is a Target Environment) and then claims are collected by the Attesting Environment. 

In the picture now, the arrow of 'Evidence of Attesters' points to the box of Lead Attester. Actually, for the previous case, the arrow should end to the Attesting Environment, and for the latter case, the arrow should end to the Target Environment.

comments.author: gmandyam
comments.body:
"After collecting the Evidence of other Attesters, this inside Verifier verifies them ...  .  Then the insider Verifier sends the Attestation Results of other Attesters, ..., to the outside Relying Party."

This is not the only approach for how a composite device would incorporate an inside Verifier.  On the arch. telco on 03-March-2020, I mentioned the example of a composite mobile device where a host processor attaches to a communications module (3.g. 5G modem) via a standard peripheral interface (PCIE, SDIO, etc..).  In this example, the host processor may leverage the attestation to ensure that it is attached to whitelisted modem.  And it won't convey the attestation results any further.

comments.author: William-PanWei
comments.body:
> "After collecting the Evidence of other Attesters, this inside Verifier verifies them ... . Then the insider Verifier sends the Attestation Results of other Attesters, ..., to the outside Relying Party."
> 
> This is not the only approach for how a composite device would incorporate an inside Verifier. On the arch. telco on 03-March-2020, I mentioned the example of a composite mobile device where a host processor attaches to a communications module (3.g. 5G modem) via a standard peripheral interface (PCIE, SDIO, etc..). In this example, the host processor may leverage the attestation to ensure that it is attached to whitelisted modem. And it won't convey the attestation results any further.

In your example, I think the entity of the host processor takes on the role of the Verifier and Relying Party, the entity of modem takes on the role of Attester. So the host processor first takes on the role of Verifier to verify the modem whether trustworthy and on the whitelist, and then it takes on the role of Relying Party to consume the Attestation Result.
As I mentioned at the beginning of this paragraph, the role combinations can be arbitrary. And this paragraph just gives one example where the entity takes on the role of Attester and Verifier, to show how role combination works.

comments.author: mcr
comments.body: Closed in favour of PR #82.

evidence -> Evidence
the device -> Attester
Are the Attester and Verifier different entities? If they are different, how can the Verifier know the Attester has a secure element?
So you mean the Evidence isn't signed or encrypted?
nit: "e.g." should always have a comma immediately after it
I don't think we should use the term "secure element" in lower case, as it's ambiguous whether we mean Secure Element (per GP) or something more generic
I don't think the word endorsement is accurate here.   Perhaps you mean signature?  (Which is already after the "or") so recommend deleting the endorsement phrase.
Dave Thaler asks for rewording to make the Implicit Trust more clear, the secure session is necessary, but not sufficient for this.  MCR asks for the example to not be parenthetical.

Endorsements are signed (integrity protected and authenticated) by supply chain entity such as a vendor or manufacturer. Evidence is signed by an attestation key that is on the attesting device. The roles architecture distinguishes between Endorsers and Attesters for good reasons even though there can be cases where it isn't that clear that they are different. I don't think this section is trying to draw attention to one of those corner cases. Therefore, it appears the term Endorsement was used by mistake when Evidence was intended.

@nedmsmith 

That wasn't really the intention behind the cited text.  If the communications link is already trusted, then an endorsement may have been used in establishing the communications link.  In that case, an additional endorsement for attestation evidence is not required.

I agree with the three sentences above.

I think the text at line 616 may be what is the problem because it presumes knowledge of the secure element context is existential. The Verifier needs to be told that the root-of-trust / secure element environment exists. It can happen manually, such as an IT department physically issuing a smart card or smart device with a SE to a user, generating the key pair, update the Verifier to trust the public that was generated. Manual approaches work in IT environments where employees are subject to IT procedures. Manual processes may not scale to Internet ecosystems. Remote attestation is trying to go beyond manual processes by generating keys in devices by manufacturers and issuing machine certs that establish that a key is protected by a secure element. This seems like a basic idea that if it isn't clear might belong in the introduction?

```suggestion
the Evidence is conveyed. As an example, the Attester and Verifier can
```

```suggestion
communicate over a link that is established using a Root of Trust.  An example of such communications
```

```suggestion
element (e.g., SIM card).  The Verifier may have established the communications link and verified
```

```suggestion
the presence of the Root-of-Trust in doing so, or may have received evidence that the communications
```

```suggestion
transient nature of the communications link security.  For instance, once the link is torn down
```

```suggestion
then the Evidence may not be trusted until it is conveyed again over a re-established link.
```

Need more explanation about what "anchored to a Root of Trust" means.  To trust the evidence, you have to have some assurance that the evidence is correct, and wasn't just fed to the communication link endpoint by some untrusted party.
The use of 'endorsement' is deliberate.  Any endorsement would be applied to assertions associated with the communications link, not the attestation evidence.

What about the following:

"... or may have received evidence that the communications link is anchored to a Root of Trust from an entity that established the communications link.  In the latter case, anchoring the communications link to a Root of Trust would mean that  this entity only established a communications link with the attesting device after verifying that the device had a Root of Trust."
Changes to "enclave" as per RFC 4949
That wasn't obvious from "additional".  Need to reword.

comments.author: nedmsmith
comments.body:
The existing text listed HSM and TEE as examples of Attesting Environments. However, an HSM that only provides crypto acceleration and key storage wasn’t designed for claims collection. Therefore, it isn’t an Attesting Environment (necessarily).

The text I added explains that the Attesting Environment is designed in such a way that it is capable of claims collection. For example, if the HSM was designed to have exposed a shared memory region that is shared with the Target Environment’s executable code pages.

pulls.author: mcr

comments.body: "A piece of asserted information, often in the form of a name/value pair."

Thomas Hardjono
This is what th SAML standard says: An assertion is a package of information that supplies zero or more statements made (about subject)

I don't feel strongly about using 'subject' but it isn't used anywhere else whereas we use 'entity' elsewhere. If the reader knows we meant 'entity' even though we used 'subject' then it is OK. However, it might be just as easy to say entity and not introduce the question in the readers mind whether subject has special meaning or not. We use entity 29 times already. We use 'subject' once but for a different meaning.
One minor question: if we define the term Claim, do we need to further change the 'claim' now in the whole doc to capitalized 'Claim'?

The word 'asserted' is ambiguous / dissonant - leading the reader to wonder if this is a loaded word - but without context or resolution. I also don't know if by saying to 'compare' to JWT use of 'claim' whether this spec uses it synonymously or if the reader is supposed to look for and internalize how they differ.

Being explicit is better IMO. "A piece of information, often in the form of a name/value pair, that can be asserted as Evidence, Endorsements or Attestation Results."

pulls.title: Time considerations
pulls.author: dthaler
pulls.body: Add time considerations into an appendix and reference it from the freshness section.

comments.author: dthaler
comments.body:
For readability, I have removed extraneous event times and only kept the ones used in the discussion after at least one diagram.
My goal is to keep the discussion easy to understand and not include excess details or complexity that could be left to other docs.

comments.author: mcr
comments.body:
@henkbirkholz will look into additions around purple items. 
@nedmsmith to work on moving table to section 9 (freshness)

I think there is a difference between the time a value was generated/created and the time it was collected into a claim. Example: FW is updated on Tuesday but Attesting environment does't run until Wednesday. If the objective is to identify all the points where time could play a role, VG seems to conflate two events.

In a hybrid use case involving multiple Relying Parties, there will be a case where the first RP may issue a result expiry (RX) that is different from the RX supplied by the Verifier. Maybe it is better name it (VX) for Verifier use and allow (RX) for use by Relying Parties?
Shouldn't 'Nonce' be returned to Verifier from RP?

My opinion: I don't think it should be a goal to identify "all the points where time could play a role", just "all the points where the discussion in this section needs to reference in some specific security check for freshness/recency".

That's why I removed events that were not referenced in any check in any example.   Any request to add another row should, in my view, come with proposed text that includes a specific security check equation that requires it.

See earlier response about not adding rows unless/until there is text explaining what security test it's required for.  Feel free to suggest text explaining what security threat is relevant and what check some party would do to mitigate it.
Yes thanks.  Fixed diagram.

The examples use RATS Roles context to show relevance of the time consideration. The roles architecture doesn't elevate Attesting Environment and Target Environment to the same status (not arguing to do that either). There is however time considerations that apply between TE and AE interactions. The security consideration (which may be contrived) is that the target environment may exhibit one set of claims at value creation and a different set at value collection / measurement. This could happen if attack code has control of the TE and presents one set of claims at time of collection then reverts back to the other set (and presumably continues execution with the attacker's claims). I can convince myself that if the AE and TE were secure by design, that the scenario shouldn't happen. However, it is a common mistake that measurement of code is taken before it is loaded, but modified after being loaded, but the collected evidence always reports what was though to be loaded not what is actually loaded. If it is important to capture this common mistake. Maybe it belongs in security considerations?

According to Ned's assumption, here is the case: Verifier -> RP1 -> RP2. The verifier gives a result expiry time in the Attestation Result to RP1. RP2 gives another result expiry to RP2. So RP2 has 2 result expiry times. Maybe Ned wants to emphasize that RP2 has to make a choice between these two times.
But RP can also have other expiry policies that come from other sources, e.g., the administrator configures an expiry time. I think it's up to the implementation to consider how to make decisions among all the policies. What is important here, however, is that the Attestation Result can contain an ‘expiry’ claim.

I think you meant "RP1 gives another result expiry to RP2". I suppose it isn't clear whether RP1 can supply RX or if it only can supply RR. If RX is only a function of a Verifier then the use case doesn't make sense. If RX can be asserted by RP to other RPs, then that implies RX can be a "Remediation action" from a RP; which we said might be OK for TEEP arch to define but is likely out of scope for RATS. I prefer to place limits on "who can say what" to limit combinatorics and therefore limits the potential for insecure states. Dave T. seems to be saying that unless there is a use case, it doesn't make sense to define the freshness variable. But even with already defined variables it is possible to find insecure states unless some other constraints are acknowledged. Maybe both perspectives can be held simultaneously? 

Even if we limit RX to Verifier only. An (out-of-scope?) RP1 to RP2 flow could define different RX (RX2) that leaves RP2 in the same undecidability state that Pan Wei points out. But I don't think the arch can prevent the possibility for unsecure states. Nevertheless, I'm still an advocate for specifying which entity is expected to make which freshness claim. Put the burden of proof on the use case to justify when it makes sense for other entities to make the freshness claim.

pulls.title: An update to Freshness
pulls.author: henkbirkholz
pulls.body: Sry, for the included conflict to references. Should have checked master first....

comments.author: thomas-fossati
comments.body:
General comment / suggestion.  I don't think we should go in great details here.  It's good to provide a bit of context and clarifying information around freshness, but I don't see the need for a big taxonomical effort :-)

I think the concepts could be condensed in a couple of paragraphs, like:
```
Freshness has two dimensions: recentness and uniqueness.

Uniqueness is conveyed via a non-repeatable value sourced, for example,
from a high quality randomness pool, a “granular enough” clock, a serial
number that doesn’t wrap-around, etc.  In the context of Evidence and
Attestation Results, uniqueness can be encoded into a "nonce" attribute.

Recentness is conveyed via either a relative or absolute timestamp - 
associated with the time of collection of claims by the attester, or the
time the attestation report is produced — and an either explicit
or implicit “expiry” value that determines the threshold between
acceptable (i.e. recent enough) and non-acceptable (i.e., too old)
values of the timestamp. It assumes time synchronisation between
producers and consumers.    In the context of Evidence and Attestation
Results, recentness can be encoded using a "timestamp" and "expiry"
attributes.
```
or similar.  Cheers!

comments.author: henkbirkholz
comments.body: I agree that is not necessary to start a taxonomy here ). It would be very tiny in any way. I think that it would suffice to say that recentness and uniqueness are the two vital parts of freshness with respect to evidence (attestation results work differently, they are literally more like actual tokens and could come with an expiration date aka a period of validity).

comments.author: henkbirkholz
comments.body:
Reading the whole exchange again - how about:

```
Freshness of the content of Conceptual Messages has two dimensions:
recentness and uniqueness.
 
Uniqueness of Conceptual Messages can be conveyed via an included,
non-repeatable value sourced, for example, from a high quality randomness pool,
a “granular enough” clock, a serial number that doesn’t wrap-around, etc.  In the
context of Evidence and Attestation Results, uniqueness can be encoded into a
"nonce" attribute.
 
Recentness of Evidence can be conveyed either via a protocol processing a
non-repeatable value (as illustrated above) in a hand-shake interaction or via a
payload including a relative or absolute timestamp associated with the time of
collection of Claims by the Attester, or the time the attestation Evidence is produced.
Recentness of Conceptual Messages can also be determined by either an explicit
or implicit “expiry” value that determines the threshold between acceptable
(i.e. recent enough) and non-acceptable (i.e., too old) values of the timestamp.
It assumes time synchronization between producers and consumers.
```

The sentences are still a bit long, but for the moment the more important question is,
if @thomas-fossati would agree with this text that I based on his proposal?

comments.author: dthaler
comments.body: I don't understand why we care about uniqueness in this document.  The text does not justify why uniqueness matters for any security purpose.   Maybe a protocol can discuss it but I don't yet see why it should be mentioned in this doc.

comments.author: thomas-fossati
comments.body:
> The sentences are still a bit long, but for the moment the more important question is,
> if @thomas-fossati would agree with this text that I based on his proposal?

Thanks @henkbirkholz for trying to draft a compromise.

There are some things in your write up that needs further clarification and others that seem a bit redundant and can be easily trimmed.  

Among the first set I think one key clarification is the one around:
```
Recentness of Evidence can be conveyed [...] via a protocol processing a
non-repeatable value (as illustrated above) in a hand-shake interaction
```
which, IMO, falls a bit too short defining exactly how uniqueness can help with recentness, which seems to be your main point.

The way I understand it, is that nonce's non-repeatability used in a transaction involving an initiator and a responder (possibly what you call "hand-shake interaction" above?) allows the initiator to lock a specific portion of time, i.e., to define two very specific events: a begin and an end.  If the initiator happens to also have:
1) a clock, and
2) a notion of expiry

then some form of _rough_ recentness, i.e., one that:

1) can't distinguish between creation time and collection time of claims;
2) applies to the whole claims set as opposed to individual claims

can be built even _without_ a synchronised clock at the responder.

Is this what the quoted sentence really means to you?

If so, I think we can craft some text together that is short and to the point.

That said, and again thanks very much for this further edit pass, I'd be still OK with just dropping this PR altogether.

comments.author: henkbirkholz
comments.body: Because it is one of two primary enabler of recentness as a part of freshness, I think. And I think we care a lot about fresh evidence in this architecture document. Can you think of a better place for this? I still think the characteristics of "freshness" are quite fundamental to the RATS concepts, yes? And an architecture provides the fundamental concepts for protocol design, I think.

comments.author: henkbirkholz
comments.body: @thomas-fossati, yes that is a way more detailed description of what my (rather short) was intended to capture :-)

comments.author: thomas-fossati
comments.body: Freshness is dealt with in #91
This part doesn't make sense for Attestation Results in my opinion.

```suggestion
two characteristics that can be part of freshness are further elaborated below,
```

In general this may not be correct since it may be about the time a claim value was generated rather than the time the evidence was generated.   Or perhaps maybe that's a third term and defining terms is not a good direction...
"sealing via signing" seems over-specific to me (I commented similarly on #85).  I'd drop it and just leave "(typically by sealing a Claims set)"
I'm slightly confused: nonce is about uniqueness, not recentness.

Unless I'm missing something big, this sentence looks like a truism to me?
I think this should state what defines the "too old" criterion.
While I understand your point of view.... I literally strongly disagree. It very much can be used specifically for recentness in the context of CHARRA.
pls, see below

I understand the specifics of a "Secure Channel" that would not require sealing. As this is covered by Giri's PR, I deliberately highlighted "the other"/"most common" way to inhibit tampering here. And I think that is okay, still, taking your comment into account.

pls, see the #88 

We have to "qualify" this step well. I am happy to read alternatives. It remains to be vital independent of phrasing, I think.

Correct. That is a content oversight! It's on my list, but I made an error here by omitting that.

Attestation Results have a certain "time interval of validity", which we have not talked about at all, yet? I assume?
I'm not sure why this should be Evidence specific?  (This also applies to Recentness above.)
The thing I wanted to say is that any concept of "recentness" must come with an (either explicit or implicit) "max-age" label, otherwise it isn't actionable.
Sorry, I can't see anything below, even after refreshing the page.

Example: a nonce provided by a Verifier in a network protocol to retrieve Evidence from an Attester that is subsequently used in creating the Evidence enables a Verifier to assert that the reply from the Attester including the evidence was created upon the just emitted request of the Verifier; therefore establishing the most common method of providing a proof-of-recentness via a challenge/response remote attestation (CHARRA).

Maybe I am missing something obvious here, but how is this mechanic not addressing the appraisal of "recent creation of evidence"?
Sry. "Below" was meant to refer to a different comment of yours on lines 376-379 (I am not sure how to ref that comment here).

The entire text I wrote was Evidence-specific. Your comment relates to Dave's on lines 340+343 ("above"). I am hesitant to extend this beyond the scope of Evidence and Attestation Results (the latter is missing). Would the scope of Evidence + Attestation Results be okay?
In the example you make it's the _uniqueness_ property of the nonce that guarantees that the Evidence is fresh.  A nonce bears no recentness.

Then no value, including the timestamp of a certificate, bears inherent recentness characteristics, yes?

But that is not correct in the context of the Challenge/Response handshake. Again, maybe I am missing something very obvious. Could you provide me with a protocol-based exemplary use of a nonce, generated by the challenger, where the reply that uses the nonce (most likely in a "sealed" way, such as digital signing) does not bear a proof-of-recentness by using that nonce in its reply?

An additional clarifying comment:

If you add a timestamp that was generated on a responder in evidence, the "meaning of recentness it bears" is based on a trust relationship created by an endorser that vouches for the fact that "timestamps from that attestation Evidence provenance" are to be trusted. Alternatively, a challenger can simply establish a similar bi-lateral trust relationship by conducting a Challenge/Response handshake here. It is a smaller scoped trust relationship, it is temporary, and the challenger must at least be RESTful in order not to forget that it created the nonce in the Challenge. But then - in this context - the nonce created by the challenger "bears recentness" from the point of view of the Challenger, I would think.

The max-age in this case is not included in the evidence as a value, it is simply state (like... a Verifier measuring a time interval to the best of its capability) maintained by the challenger. In that way, like a secure channel enabling you to omit a signature, the nonce enables you to omit a max-age while retaining being actionable.

I assume that you would see this as the concept of providing an 'implicit "max-age" label'. The use of a nonce explicitly enables that, I think.

> Then no value, including the timestamp of a certificate, bears inherent recentness characteristics, yes?

Not by itself.  You also need a synchronised clock and an expiry threshold to determine “freshness by recentness”, at least in the sense I intend it.

> But that is not correct in the context of the Challenge/Response handshake. Again, maybe I am missing something very obvious. Could you provide me with a protocol-based exemplary use of a nonce, generated by the challenger, where the reply that uses the nonce (most likely in a "sealed" way, such as digital signing) does not bear a proof-of-recentness by using that nonce in its reply?

This is IMO “freshness by uniqueness”, in fact it doesn’t require a clock nor an expiry to work, just a non-repeating source of byte strings.

I guess my main point here is the following: if we need to go into the semantic finesse of distinguishing between the recentness and uniqueness aspects of freshness, then we need to make it worth the words we spend by _clearly_ separating the two.

Since I've diluted it across a few different comments, it's maybe worth summing up the way I see the distinction working in practice :
- uniqueness needs a source of non-repeatable byte strings and is completely driven by the requestor;
- recentness needs synchronised clocks between requestor and responder and is conveyed via a timestamp plus an expiration threshold associated with the provided evidence / attestation result.

The problem I have with the current text when it says that nonces convey recentness is it seems to be blurring that distinction, therefore voiding the overall "semantic finesse" plan :-)

> > Then no value, including the timestamp of a certificate, bears inherent recentness characteristics, yes?
> 
> Not by itself. You also need a synchronised clock and an expiry threshold to determine “freshness by recentness”, at least in the sense I intend it.

Then I agree that without context, values never bear a meaning of recentness.



> > Then no value, including the timestamp of a certificate, bears inherent recentness characteristics, yes?
> 
> Not by itself. You also need a synchronised clock and an expiry threshold to determine “freshness by recentness”, at least in the sense I intend it.
> 
> > But that is not correct in the context of the Challenge/Response handshake. Again, maybe I am missing something very obvious. Could you provide me with a protocol-based exemplary use of a nonce, generated by the challenger, where the reply that uses the nonce (most likely in a "sealed" way, such as digital signing) does not bear a proof-of-recentness by using that nonce in its reply?
> 
> This is IMO “freshness by uniqueness”, in fact it doesn’t require a clock nor an expiry to work, just a non-repeating source of byte strings.

Well, the Verifier has to retain state, "remembering the nonce" until a certain time-out, which I think most certainly requires a clock. Otherwise, networks protocols would have a hard time.

The curious mixture of "freshness by uniqueness" is exactly the reason why I wrote the text. Typically "freshness" is used without context here. And we decided to provide more context because it is not "freshness by uniqueness" but "recentness & uniqueness" called freshness for simplicity, I think.

> I guess my main point here is the following: if we need to go into the semantic finesse of distinguishing between the recentness and uniqueness aspects of freshness, then we need to make it worth the words we spend by _clearly_ separating the two.

Absolutely agreed.

> * uniqueness needs a source of non-repeatable byte strings and is completely driven by the requestor;
> 
> * recentness needs synchronised clocks between requestor and responder and is conveyed via a timestamp plus an expiration threshold associated with the provided evidence / attestation result.

I am not entirely sure that uniqueness is always completely driven by the challenger/requester, but it most certainly can and is.

I agree that recentness is based on synchronization and timestamps in TUDA, of course. I still do not understand how that is required for a Challenge/Response handshake, because there are conveyance mechanisms today that only need a clock on the Challenger side, measuring the time between a Challenge including a nonce and a Response including a digest of the nonce (in a secure channel or digitally signed).

 

> The problem I have with the current text when it says that nonces convey recentness is it seems to be blurring that distinction, therefore voiding the overall "semantic finesse" plan :-)

You are correct that a nonce value by itself does not convey recentness :-) We wildly agree that even timestamp values do not do that. I think that is typically way harder to agree on. A nonce in a Challenge/Response interaction does convey recentness, but due to the context of the protocol mechanism - not by the value itself. I tried to always provide the context of the interaction model in the text, but i seems I was not successful with that.

> Well, the Verifier has to retain state, "remembering the nonce" until a certain time-out, which I think most certainly requires a clock. Otherwise, networks protocols would have a hard time.

I disagree, the existence of a garbage collector that sweeps allocated nonces at regular intervals (i.e., the "remembering until time-out") is just an implementation detail, it's not fundamental.

What a nonce gives you is the assurance that *when* the transaction completes -- maybe one ms after the end of the universe! ;-) -- the response you get back is uniquely bound to your original request and there is no other transaction that could have produced the same response.  This is what I mean by freshness by uniqueness, which doesn't imply time and therefore clocks to measure it.

Okay :-) Let me rephrase that. A Challenger that intends to retrieve Evidence in a finite time, has a clock, and that intends to obtain a notion of recentness can track a time interval only using its clock to do this. The indicator for the duration here (duration being a time interval where the left time is an epoch starting with 0 at which the Challenge including a nonce is emitted and at the right time evidence including a digest of a nonce is received) is the time that has passed between Challenge and Response.

Very small RESTful interactions as enabled via CoAP enable this (even with using an observe option) notion of recentness - intrinsically. Retaining state for an operation is not an implementation detail, I think. It is, for example required to associate CoAP tokens. Typically protocols use time-outs to avoid waiting until the end of the universe - and I think that is not an implementation detail, too, but an interaction model capability. The binding to what you call an transaction here, which typically is a operation I think, is what is the essential part to get a notion of recentness. 

In contrast to your point, my point is that a re-use of a nonce that is cryptographically (and in this case uniquely) "bound" to a Response does not require synchronized clocks due to the "recentness" based on the uniqueness that is provided by the "arbitrary number used only once in a cryptographic communication" (nonce) intrinsically.

Edit: maybe this will also help us to converge here :-)
RFC4949 definition of a nonce
A random or non-repeating value that is included in data exchanged by a protocol, usually for the purpose of guaranteeing liveness and thus detecting and protecting gainst replay attacks.

In consequence, I think:

1.) "recentness by uniqueness" is an over-simplification (you could receive two responses based on the same nonce, violating uniqueness wrt the nonce, and still only process the most recent response via sequence or clock use), and
2.) "recentness needs synchronized clocks between requestor and responder and is conveyed via a timestamp plus an expiration threshold associated with the provided evidence / attestation result." is not correct, due to being too specific (you do not always need synchronized clocks) and unnecessary limiting (you do not necessarily need time-stamps and or expiration dates).

If I would only look at the interaction model of TUDA, I would agree! :-) But looking at charra, tuda and subscribed evidence, I think I still cannot agree.

Edit: I think I have to highlight that this is about the conveyance of evidence - only! As noted in another comment, a "time of validity" for, e.g. Attestation Results, is another matter of "freshness" that is not addressed in the current text.
OK, it seems like we agree to disagree then :-)

I assume there is common ground somewhere :-) Illustrating the different aspects about freshness for conceptual messages generally, might help us to converge maybe? Appraisal Policies enable a period or maybe even duration of validity for Attestation Evidence. Then synchronized clocks are a vital part here. 

Also, there might be other opinions out there?

> I assume there is common ground somewhere :-) 

As much as I'd like to, I think our paths diverge a bit too early to try and reconcile.

Re-reading your last batch of replies, though, I've found something I think you are 100% correct:

> you do not always need synchronized clocks

true!  You only need that when the requestor depends on an _explicit_ timestamp set by the responder.
I also think the time of reception is not particularly interesting, and the phrasing in 376 is not correct.  What's interesting is the time of appraisal, which is time(RG).
@thomas-fossati the nonce is about freshness.  See discussion of examples 2 and 4 in sections 15.2 and 15.4 in the editors copy.
I don't understand why this discussion is needed/relevant.   (I might understand it in the context of a specific protocol/mechanism, but I don't understand why it belongs in the architecture.)
@dthaler I certainly agree nonce is about freshness.  What I am arguing here (and in the following, long-winded discussion) is that a nonce creates freshness by "uniqueness" rather than "recentness".

As various individuals seem to have 2+ points of view on this, I'd assume this will create a severe caveat, if not illustrated and unambiguously resolved in the architecture I-D . In the end, if we do not agree on this intuitively, how is the architecture doc not in charge of preventing this - obviously now identified - cause of confusion to other readers?
why not just say "using the latest Appraisal Policy for the latest Evidence"
Stick to upper case Evidence convention. Since we defined Evidence as Claims that are signed (protected) we don't have to restate it here.
Intuitively, recentness is the time of claims collection or the time of appraisal. Do we need more than this?
Intuitively freshness is the time since the request was made and the response was received. Do we need more than this?

I think the uniqueness property is addressed by the credential used to authenticate the Attester to the Verifier (and subsequently used to integrity protect the Evidence messages). If the credential uniquely identifies the Attester then the Evidence is unique to the session to which the authentication applies. 
If the credential is a group credential (e.g. EPID / DAA) then the uniqueness is to the members of the group. We have other sections on Privacy and authentication of the endpoint. (Or maybe I'm wrong about the latter). But it might make sense to have a section on "Authentication of the Endpoint" as the way to talk about security properties of uniqueness / non-uniqueness?

time(AA) seems to be irrelevant for any security purpose, only time(EG) is relevant, so I don't think time(AA) belongs in this doc.

time(HD) also seems very confusing.   since time(HD) and time(EG) are on the same entity, and that same entity compares against a threshold, what security threat is this trying to address?  I don't follow.
there is no time(CC) in the diagram, but I think time(CC) is irrelevant for any security purpose, only time(EG) matters and time(CC) can be ignored

In order to always create the most recent Evdence possible, the Attester has to be aware of a changed Value as soon as possible. Otherwise Evidence is outdated and could even convey a misleading picture about an Attester's Target Environments, ultimately leading to incorrect risk assessments. Hence time(AA) is quite relevant, I think. 

There are scenarios where this is less relevant (e.g. boot-time integrity) and some scenarios where this is more relevant (e.g. run-time integrity).

I agree that time(HD) is "squeezed" into the diagram it is actually the reception of the distributed handles. I did not want to add a "distributor of the handles" the the actors in the diagram. Maybe we can address this by rewording time(HD) correspondingly? In essence, I understand why this is difficult to follow at the moment and we have to fix this.
I think that we can actually skip time(CC). It seemed important to various people, but I can see how you can work around that just with time(AA) and time(EG). Other thoughts?
Agreed that "HD" is not a good term, but a better term will be worked on.

pulls.title: Freshness section slight reorg
pulls.author: thomas-fossati
pulls.body:
This commit slightly changes the Freshness section to reflect the
outcome of the discussion around PR #87.  (Hopefully I've managed to
capture the gist of Henk's thinking without disrupting too much the
existing flow.)

TL;DR

The key change here is the removal of reply protection as a goal in
itself.  The section now states clearly that the overall goal is instead
the identification of the point in time when attestation claims have
been signed and/or generated so that a freshness policy can be applied.
In this perspective, the fundamental property provided by a nonce-based
scheme with regards to freshness is its ability to lock the requester's
clock to the underlying protocol transaction, thus indirectly
establishing the epoch of the attestation / verification event.  By
making the nonce unique and non-predictable, the timeline locking cannot
be subverted, which provides anti-replay.  However, that is a nice
side-effect rather than the primary goal.

This commit also adds some precision around the nonce and clock
properties - unpredictability and trustworthiness respectively.

The essential premise is on [this line](https://github.com/ietf-rats-wg/architecture/pull/91/files#diff-29242c163e575f8093d7e76443c9d1d2R880). In particular, by using "solely" I wanted to discuss the case where the only clock that the appraiser can trust is its own.  The intent of the [following text](https://github.com/ietf-rats-wg/architecture/pull/91/files#diff-29242c163e575f8093d7e76443c9d1d2R882-R883) is just to illustrate two common instances where the appraiser can't rely on the peer's clock.

The overall premise for this whole paragraph is that appraiser does _not_ consider any time assertion made the peer, and to determine what kind of information can be used in this case to evaluate freshness.

Clearly, once the peer's clock becomes usable - as in [this example](https://github.com/ietf-rats-wg/architecture/pull/91/files#diff-29242c163e575f8093d7e76443c9d1d2R897-R899) - then finer-grained timestamping can become input to the evaluation of the freshness policy as well.

pulls.title: More description of Endorsements
pulls.author: laurencelundblade
pulls.body: Addresses issue #65

comments.author: laurencelundblade
comments.body:
Six paragraphs for six characteristics of Endorsements

1) They are absolutely required and the sole basis of a Verifier trusting an Attester and Evidence
2) They are how key material for 1) gets to a Verifier (if not an Endorsement, how else?)
3) They are created by an Endorser
4) They must be conveyed securely from Endorser to Verifyer
5) They may contain known-good or reference values
6) They may contain static implicit claims that are passed to RP's via Attestation Results.

comments.author: dthaler
comments.body: Discussion August 25: might be worth mentioning Endorsements in Privacy Considerations section, if Endorsement might contain PII in some use case.
singular / plural agreement
Verifier isn't trying to "trust attesters" rather it is trying to Appraise Evidence.
I prefer wording closer to "without Endorsements, Appraisal lacks expected values that can be compared with actual values resulting in an inconclusive Appraisal."
Lines 741 - 743 seem redundant with regard to 739.
Suggested wording change "Endorsements may include credentials for authenticating Evidence and identifying the Attesting Environment." (replaces lines 745 - 749)
Not sure lines 750 - 754 are necessary.

"Endorsements may contain reference Claims and invariant Claims. Reference Claims are expected values that can be compared to actual values supplied as Evidence. Invariant Claims are static values that always apply regardless of Attester operational states." (replaces 756 - 758)
I don't think 760 - 761 are needed.

762 - 763 is not stated correctly. Claims included in Attestation Results are no longer considered Endorsements. The section on Attestation Results should suffice as a definition of Attestation Results.
"usually" is incorrect stereotyping. Not sure 765 is adding useful information.
Lines 766 - 770 are exemplary in nature, but reads somewhat prescriptive. Suggest we re-look at "Endorser" section to see if it captures the use case intuition.
There is a section on message conveyance and on trust model. If these sections are not clear enough, maybe changes should be considered there?
I'm not sure what this sentence is saying.

I disagree with this phrasing.   Endorsements are essential for scalability.  If a Verifier owner has some means to establish trust in each Attester's hardware individually then it need not use an endorsement.  But typically that's not scalable.   Thus I prefer the original wording.

I disagree with both the proposed line 739 and Ned's statement.  Endorsements don't contain "expected values", those are obtained (if at all) in addition to the "endorsement" per se, not as part of them.  (My point is just about terminology/definition, not about the protocol where they may typically come in the same protocol as endorsements.)
Agree they're redundant, and I disagree with it for the same reason :)
I agree with Ned this is too much protocol details, and may not apply to all implementations so isn't really architectural I think.  Same goes for lines 747-749 I would say.
Agree with Ned.
This implies conveyance via a secure protocol, which I disagree is a must.  As long as endorsements are signed, how they're conveyed is irrelevant... conveyance via an insecure protocol is fine.

The architecture needs to include the Verifier knows to trust the Attester, how it gets the key material on which the trust is based.  Since the only inputs are Endorsements and Policy, Endorsement seems the better line up.
Well, yes, but if you don't trust the Attester to some degree, the Evidence is worthless. The sentence does depict that.

The Verifier has to have key material. It may also get implied or inferred claims, things it knows about the Attester that the Attester didn't tell it directly. From discussions with Henk and such, I believe both the key material and implied claims come in the form of Endorsements. Some may be known-good-values, but others may be things that are passed on the relying party.

I haven't seen the terms Reference and Invariant Claim before. They seem OK, but they seem synonymous with k-g-v or Reference Values. Are they?

Note also that I see some of these as being passed through the Verifier to the Relying Party.  I described this elaborately here: https://mailarchive.ietf.org/arch/msg/rats/VS-pAO2Io33EagbtpLutIrnUpAQ/
Seemed like the term Endorser was eliminated. I was trying to work around that.
I used the term "secure way" to cover signing and even an in person delivery of flash drive. (I have actually done this with VeriSign root).
Was going to review (and probably comment) on Trust Model next. :-)
I didn't write it. It's what was in the section before. Shows up in the diff because I split it into a separate paragraph. I'm a bit unsure about it myself.

reviews.author: mcr
reviews.body: I don't see this as improving the text.

comments.body: I prefer the old text.
I still have the same objection as before to this text.   (And I don't think new text is required either.)
I still have the same objection to this text as before.
I don't see the point of calling this out for endorsements more than other messages.   (Personally I think it's already sufficiently covered in the doc for messages in general.)
Do you think that Endorsements are not always required or do you agree with me that they are always required but the text here is redundant?
Sorry, but I'm not able to figure out which previous comment applies to which line here.

Not always required.  The relevant part of my earlier comment above is "If a Verifier owner has some means to establish trust in each Attester's hardware individually then it need not use an endorsement."

It was.  "This implies conveyance via a secure protocol, which I disagree is a must. As long as endorsements are signed, how they're conveyed is irrelevant... conveyance via an insecure protocol is fine."   Line 750 is better but to me it just explains in the text why the text in 749 is not correct.

There are many sentences under Trust Model about the RP trusting the Verifier, more than I have here. 

There are also many sentences about the Endorser trusting the Verifier (the flip of what I am trying to convey) in the Trust Model section.

So there's precedent in the doc for text like I'm proposing and as far as I can see little text that is redundant with mine.

I'm OK taking this out if there's consensus. If we take it out maybe we consider taking out other text about other messages?

I've used the term "secure way" to attempt to cover all manner and means to secure the conveyance, not just to refer to channel-securing protocol like TLS and IPsec. I don't mean to say you must use TLS or IPsec. Sending a signed message over plain HTTP is fine and I would call that a "secure way". Hand carrying a USB flash drive from one company to another is also a "secure way".

So maybe we agree about the concept, but the words need improving?
Maybe, text like this: if the Endorsement is not self-securing by signing or such, then some other secure means of conveyance should be used.
Added a few sentences to clarify use of signed and unsigned Endorsements.

The trusting of an Attester by a Verifier is to me one of the most fundamental things about attestation and I think it needs to be address prominently and clearly in the architecture document.

I don't know of anyway practical way to establish this trust other than with crypto which of course means some key material in the Attester and related key material in the Verifier.

If an Endorsement is not the one true way the Verifier gets the key it needs, then the architecture should indicate an input to the Verifier by which it does get the key.

I do take it that you agree that these are all valid ways for the Verifier to get the key
 - In an X.509 certificate
 - A CMS-encrypted flat file of keys
 - A flash drive from the Attester maker walked into the server room containing the Verifier
 - TLS-secured access to a database of millions of keys at the Attester manufacturer
 - Many more...

Another option here is to abandon the term Endorsement. It does seem to have some problematic preconception (I keep seem to be guessing wrong, probably because I don't go to the right TCG meetings). Instead of Endorsement these are the verifier inputs:
  - Keys
  - Known-good / Reference values
  - Implicit claims
  - Policy configuration, scripts and such.
r6 contains "Endorser:" definition.
779 should read: "Thus, when Evidence and Endorsements are used together..."

> The trusting of an Attester by a Verifier is to me one of the most fundamental things about attestation and I think it 
> needs to be address prominently and clearly in the architecture document.

Of course.

> I don't know of anyway practical way to establish this trust other than with crypto which of course means some key material in the Attester and related key material in the Verifier.

Yes.

> If an Endorsement is not the one true way the Verifier gets the key it needs, then the architecture should indicate an input to the Verifier by which it does get the key.

If you have an Endorsement, the Verifier needs a way to get the manufacturer's key and establish trust in it.
Without an Endorsement, that same mechanism applies to the Attester's key directly.
Endorsements just provide scalability since you can put one key in your trust anchor store rather than (say) 1 per Attester.

An Endorsement is simply one external key (typically a manufacturer but need not be) vouching for the Attesting Environment's key.

> I do take it that you agree that these are all valid ways for the Verifier to get the key
[...]

Yes

> Another option here is to abandon the term Endorsement.

I would disagree with that option.  The notion of an external key vouching for the Attesting Environment's key is a key concept.   As you state, it's not the only input to the Verifier but that doesn't mean the term isn't an important concept to explain.
