pulls.title: time sequence diagram changes (was issue #111) .
pulls.author: henkbirkholz
pulls.body:
Issue #111 points out that PR #88 and PR #91 have been merged prematurely.

This PR provides a fix for Issue #111:

* the lost "example 3" in Appendix A is re-added
* a new separate 4 is added (the previous example 4 is now example 5)
* the individual detailed comments itemized in Issue #111 should be addressed

comments.body:
```suggestion

[XXX- this requires an adopted cite-able document]
```
Whose clock is addressed by time HD?

the term "domain" is undefined
```suggestion
| HR | Handle received          | A centrally generated handle for time-bound freshness is received.
```
None of the others start with "The time when", it's all about the event not the time.
Also if it's time received, then "distributed" is the wrong term, "received" should be used.
Isn't this part covered by PR 124 now?   can remove from this one or abandon this one if other PRs will cover it
I can't understand the phrase from "for explicit" until the end of the sentence.

Qualifying for what?  And we already have other sections for nonces and timestamps, I don't follow what's different about this one (especially why it would combine nonce & timestamp into one example when they're separated in the other examples)

As above, I think "distributed" is the wrong word.   And the "periodic" might(?) be too strong if talking about receive time since there might be significant jitter due to congestion, so it may not look very periodic?
"potentially latency" is bad grammar.  "potential latency"?

this diagram is confusing since there are three time(HD) that all mean different things.
Suggest using ' and '' (prime and double prime) or something similar

```suggestion
                                                               | Handle     |
```

Why do you need time(AA) and time(EG) both, instead of just using one, like time(EG) as in other examples?  In particular, there is no security check mentioned below that uses time(AA) and so that event should not be added
How is this sentence different from the other examples? (If it's not, then remove the sentence.)

There are three different time(HD)'s in the diagram, which one is this talking about?
Same for time(HD').
The sentence seems to imply it's talking about the Verifiers, but if it's just the Verifier then why are there lines to the Attester and Relying Party, with time(HD) values not used in any security check or protocol message.
This doesn't make sense.

The relevant part here is the distribution of handles. This allows for implicit time-keeping only: knowledge about "yes I have knowledge of that handle or not" is the only relevant part here. Therefore, the focus here is on very implicit time measures. Naturally they appear to be basically on the other end of the spectrum of precision compared to explicit timestamps (I write appear as time sync, trustable time, and the relevance of timestamp resolution can often be severely underestimated) . "Awareness of changes" & "Reception of Handles" are the vital parts here that you often have to fall back to in practice. That is the essence of the example: Triggers based on implicit time-keeping, such as awareness of changes (-> the reception of handles is one of them, the changes of values another).

=> Trustable freshness with the least amount of clocks used (but you still can use clocks!)

In consequence: I approve your change. In each iteration we try to align your input with the concept itself.
That is probably an artifact.

We were trying not to "make up terms" in the text for readability. From the top if my head, I can't remember why we abandoned the definition of explicit and implicit time-keeping in this section. But we discussed it. Would it help to introduce the terms earlier in the text? If not, what would help you in understanding this sentence better (except reading it until the end)? I am shying away a bit from adding more words to fix other words right now.

Things that are typically qualified are: origin of handle or intend of handle. E.g. if your handle is the hash of an external timestamp + local clock time + proof of synchronization of the two => you get TUDA. If your handle is the hash of a received nonce received during subscripton, a relative tick-counter originating from your Attesting Environment, and a reference to a global time-scale => you get Attestation Event Stream Subscription.

In general, qualifying data is used in the creation of evidence. It is a annotation of intend and context to a value. The new Restful Resources is showing a good subset in which very explicit rules enrich nonces so they become qualified data. The construction rules defined there provide a whole new spectrum of meanings/semantics to nonces (which TUDA also does, as does network device description, please see below). It is important to highlight that this "semantic enrichment" is allowed, actually used quite often in the field, and goes beyond what is typically perceived as the use of nonces (we also struggle with that until a few weeks ago, when there still was a very lob-sided focus on replay prevention in the freshness section). It is quite useful to dedicate at least one example in an Appendix to this topic, I think.

Personally, i thought "qualifying data" is a well known term, such as qualified name or such. So my ask is: is this a general misconception of mine? Think of it as nonces with a bigger scope semantics (which we call handles here). If qualifying data is really not self-explanatory, what would be a better phrasing?

I am okay with using received instead of distributed here, if that helps.

We tried to simplify text here again, to make it more readable. With simplification you sometimes break meaning, unfortunately. I admit that the resulting abstraction (boiling it down to simply periodic, which is not wrong per se, but is imprecise) is a compromise. What do others think?

We tried to pick up on the notion that time(HD) is not exactly the same time, but "good enough" or "close enough" to be used as "the same time" - if your time resolution is appropriately fine-grained. The highlighted three time(HD) are different of course if the resolution is fine enough (the same as timestamps become values of entropy - aka nonsense -  if your resolution is higher than your precision and you rely on the resolution).

Again, the proposal to use three lines instead of one was made at the last call. If seeing this as ascii art makes us not wanting to use three lines in the end but one, I am totally fine with that, personally. We still have to highlight in text that there is some variance due to network conveyance here. This is how things work today - we simply need a way to depict that in an example here. I am open to suggestions and would be okay with "one line".

Because time(AA) does not seem to be relevant wrt how solutions work in the other examples. Yet it is the vital point in time that drives this example (potentially no clocks involved, a lot of types of handles allowed). We wrote multiple text versions overtime until now and all resulted in a strange disconnect when you are very explicit about time(EG) and then suddenly you just use English text to express other points in time that are critical to secure remote attestation: "and then the most important time is when the Attesting Environment becomes aware of changes to some relevant values in Target Environments, starts to collect them in order to create the semantic Claims and finally generates the Evidence at time(EG)". There is a very confusing disconnect for the reader, why only the last time is expressed so explicitly, while the potential latency between VG and AA is the driver (or disabler!) for secure evidence here.

We are now maybe too reluctant to add more complexity and text right now. Maybe that is the primary cause for confusion, nowl. The security check you expect here is either an implementation specific one (is that okay to highlight here in the architecture?) or not conducted by the Attester but the Verifier or even at the Attestation Result appraisal stage at the Relying Party. That would create a lot of text to spell all that out. Maybe there is a simpler way to phrase it? When we read this in the editor's session, we should discuss this live.

In practice today, it is not always possible to include time(VG) as (metadata) value into evidence. Sometimes, the truth is that you can only derive time(AA). And time(VG) != time(AA). It gets even "worse" when you have no local clock and your "measure of time" is only "which handles did I already get?" All these scenarios are solvable and we do not want to include a complete problem statement here, just an example that readers faced with these kinds of challenges today can relate with.

I understand that you would like to subsume that context under time(EG) and I see how that reads simpler. I have to restate that I remain a bit worried, though, that this simplification does not reflect the real world,and could potentially lead to wrong interpretation of the security assumptions/consideration.
I assume this is addressed by one of my earlier replies. This is one of the topics that should be discussed later today (20-07-07).

If (let's say) handles are created at time(X) and received at time(Y), then time(X) is typically easily obtainable and non-ambiguous, but not very useful. time(Y) introduces a variance of uncertainty across a certain time window. Effectively, that keeps them at the same point of time in low resolution timestamps and, analogously, not, if the resolution of timestamps is fine-grained enough. As we successful avoided to talk about timestamp resolution (which is essential to remote attestation, but not to this document), we'd like to keep it that way. Therefore, the choice if it is handle generation, handle emission, or handle reception is up to us here. I'd preferred distribution (encompassing the latency by referencing the start of distribution -> emission), but I can see how the perception is always falling back to "local clocks" even if they might not be there.

Some high level context: in the end, this is for us to decide. Handle Distribution is used a lot in constraint node environments.
Sometimes things have clocks, sometimes they don't.
Sometimes you want to use a trustable central times authority, sometimes you don't.
Sometimes you can infer a time when values were generated, sometimes you can't.
Depicting permutations of combinations of all existing factors would result in 32+ examples. So that did not seem reasonable.

Hence, example 4 is composite of the most typical constraints that you encounter in IoT:

* sometimes no clocks
* sometimes no central time
* sometimes no capability for value monitoring

My personal goal is to capture these three essential items into example 4. Any help is welcome!

pulls.title: Revise Privacy Considerations
pulls.author: laurencelundblade

comments.author: mcr
comments.body: please reword in smaller chunks.

reviews.author: henkbirkholz
reviews.body: These are a few exemplary changes to better align with the architecture text. I did not go through all of the text, because I would like to see some other comments first. The style of the "strategy section" probably needs an overhaul, I'd assume.

comments.body:
```suggestion
Each deployment of remote attestation must take into account how each Claim may or may not be used in a privacy violating manner by Verifiers receiving Evidence or Relying Parties receiving Attestation Results.
```

```suggestion
Every Claim in attestation Evidence and Attestation Results is potentially PII (Personally Identifying Information) depending on the end-end use case of the remote attestation procedure.
```

```suggestion
In cases where the Attester sending Evidence is owned by the Relying Party Owner, little to no consideration for privacy is needed. In other cases, such as when a mobile phone is used to access a large number of web sites, apps and services, privacy must be considered very thoroughly.
```

```suggestion
Thus, in usage scenarios where privacy violating Claims are in the attestation Evidence, an Attester should authenticate Verifiers to know that they are trusted. 
```
Not entirely sure that this suggested change is not breaking the intent of the original text.

I don't think it's true that every claim is PII.  If someone adds a claim saying it supports a specific version of the EAT spec, just like every other device, I wouldn't call that PII.  Similarly if there is a claim that contains the current time, or a nonce supplied by a verifier, those wouldn't be PII either under any use case I can think of.   The key question is whether it significantly narrows the anonymity set (as discussed in RFC 6973).
I also think the original text in red needs to stay at the top.  PII is not the only aspect of privacy, it's just an important subset.
change 'device' to attester to be consistent use of roles terminology
Strike "Every", change "Claim" to "Claims" and change "is" to "are". Then I'm OK with the proposed new text.

The text after "Verifiers" and "Relying Parties" is redundant / unnecessary since we explain in other sections the function of Verifiers and Relying Parties. Strike "receiving Evidence" and "receiving Attestation Results"
Maybe avoid using "trusted" and instead say "Verifiers (Relying Parties) that have acceptable privacy policies".

"In cases where Evidence is owned by the Relying Party Owner, consideration for privacy may be of lesser importance. In other cases where Evidence is owned by the Attester, such as when a mobile phone is used to access a large number of web sites, applications or services, consideration for privacy may be of greater importance."

pulls.title: Security considerations: Attester and Keys
pulls.author: laurencelundblade
pulls.body: This is to partially fix #133

comments.body:
1) split lines into shorter lines in the markdown to make github diffs/comments easier.
2) "Implementors" should be "Implementers"
3) "Attestation Key Material" is capitalized but is not a formally defined term.   change to lower case or reword.

1) "devices operating system" -> "device's operating system"?
2) do constrained devices really have an "operating system" per se?  I would say no, so this may not be the right term.
3) "HW" -> "hardware"
Can't parse grammar in "a dedicated chip a TEE".  Maybe missing comma?

Can't parse "mobile phone of FIDO authenticator".  Maybe "of" -> "or"?

Also it's not just about trusting the device per se (which to me implies just hardware), but about trusting the relevant software too (or the "Attester").
modify != monitor.   Just because you want to monitor something doesn't imply it's ok to modify it.   If there is a need to modify, it comes from something other than just "trying to monitor" it.
Can't parse grammar in "restricting access root or system privilege"

```suggestion
At medium level security, a special restricted operating environment like a Trusted Execution Environment (TEE) might be used. In this case, only security-oriented software has access to the Attester and key material. 
```

```suggestion
Factory key provisioning is the process that occurs in the factory or elsewhere that establishes the signing key material on the device and the verification key material off the device. Sometimes this is referred to as “personalization”. 
```

```suggestion
One way to provision a key is to first generate it external to the device and then copy the key onto the device. In this case, confidentiality of the generator, as well as the path over which the key is provisioned, is necessary. This can be achieved in a number of ways.
```

```suggestion
Confidentiality can be achieved entirely with physical factory security involving no encryption at all. For low-security use cases, this might be simply locking doors and limiting personnel that can enter the factory. For high-security use cases, this might involve a special area of the factory accessible only to select security-trained personnel.
```

```suggestion
In all cases, the factory process must be sure that it only establishes key material in Attesters that are made by the manufacturer and configured correctly. For many use cases, this will involve physical security at the factory, for example to make sure an attacker doesn't do a "midnight" production run of some counterfeit or incorrectly configured devices.
```

Comment: a lot of this section would also apply to the process by which an owner-generated (or other third-party generated) certificate is generated for the device.  This is important for cases where the verifier uses endorsements from a party other than the manufacturer, whether instead of or in addition to the manufacturer's.
Yes I think this content is useful, so comments below try to clean it up a bit.  Also some parts below might be more generalizable beyond just the manufacturer, as noted below.

This reads to me as of the Attester should be isolated (e.g. air-gap). What it should read like is that there are components in an Attester that have to be trustworthy due to isolation or shielding. Would others please reply to this comment here and highlight if they agree or not?

I would really recommend to prevent the usage of the term "Attestation" as a stand-alone term here. Please elaborate on the goals that are intended to be achieved here (as a replacement for "Attestation") instead.

```suggestion
It is assumed that the Attester is located in an isolated environment of a device like a process, a dedicated chip a TEE or such that collects the Claims, formats them and signs them with an Attestation Key. The Attester must be protected from unauthorized modification to ensure it behaves correctly. There must also be confidentiality so that the signing key is not captured and used elsewhere to forge evidence.
```

```suggestion
Implementers need to pay close attention to the isolation and protection of the Attester and the factory processes for provisioning the Attestation Key Material. When either of these are compromised, the remote attestation becomes worthless because the attacker can forge Evidence.
```
(did not address grammar issues as highlighted by Dave)

If find this sentence a bit confusing to read:

Please highlight whyt a user or owner must not be able to modify or inspect an Attester. Do you mean effectively the Attesting Environment of the Attester? That would make way more sense to me.

Why would you want a user/owner of a phone to provide biometric digests, pins or passwords, if you do not trust her in the first place?

"The point of the attestation": I really do not know what that means here. Please remove 'attestation' and elaborate on the goal of evidence generation earlier in the text please. Alternatively, "remote attestation procedure" might already be good enough?
I don't understand what problem is intended to be addressed here in the first place, unfortunately.
Now I would have expected a "low level of security" earlier in the text :-)

```suggestion
One way to provision a key is to first generate it external to the device and then copy the secret key on to the device. In this case confidentiality of the path over which the key is provisioned is necessary. This can be achieved in a number of ways.
```

```suggestion
Confidentiality can be achieved entirely with physical factory security involving no encryption at all. For low-security use cases this might be simply locking doors and limiting personal that can enter the factory. For high-security use cases this might involve a special area of the factory accessible only to select, security trained personnel.
```

```suggestion
Cryptography can also be used to support confidentiality, but keys that are used to then provision attestation keys must somehow have been provisioned securely beforehand (a recursive problem).
```

```suggestion
In all cases, a factory process must ensure that only key material that is generated by the manufacturer is establishes in Attesters and then configured correctly. For many use cases, this will involve physical security at the factory, for example to ensure an attacker doesn’t do a “midnight” production run of some counterfeit or incorrectly configured devices.
```
I think I know what a 'midnight run' is. Does everybody else?

```suggestion
Remote attestation applies to use cases with a range of security requirements, so the protections discussed here range from low to high security where low security  may be only application or process isolation by the device's operating system and high security involves specialized hardware to defend against physical attacks on a chip.
```

```suggestion
In many cases the user or owner of the device must not be able to modify or exfiltrate keys from the Attesting Environment of the Attester. 
For example the owner or user of a mobile phone or FIDO authenticator is not trusted. 
The point of remote attestation is for the Relying Party to be able to trust the Attester even though they don’t trust the user or owner. 
```

```suggestion
```

```suggestion
Some of the measures for low level security include process or application isolation by a high-level operating system, and perhaps restricting access to root or system privilege. For extremely simple single-use devices that don’t use a protected mode operating system, like a Bluetooth speaker, the isolation might only be the plastic housing for the device.
```

```suggestion
```

```suggestion
In all cases, the factory process must ensure that only key material that is generated by the manufacturer is established in Attesters and then is configured correctly. For many use cases, this will involve physical security at the factory, for example to ensure an attacker can not do a "midnight" production run of some counterfeit or incorrectly configured devices.
```

```suggestion
### Attestation Key Provisioning Processes

Attestation key provisioning is the process that occurs in the factory or elsewhere that establishes the signing key material on the device and the verification key material off the device. Sometimes this is referred to as “personalization”. 
```

```suggestion
Confidentiality can be achieved entirely with physical provisioning facility security involving no encryption at all. For low-security use cases, this might be simply locking doors and limiting personnel that can enter the facility. For high-security use cases, this might involve a special area of the facility accessible only to select security-trained personnel.
```

```suggestion
In all cases, the Attestation Key provisioning process must be sure that it only establishes key material in Attesters that are made by the manufacturer and configured correctly. 
For many use cases, this will involve physical security at the facility, to prevent unauthorized devices from being manufactured that may be counterfeit or incorrectly configured.
```

```suggestion
In all cases, the Attestation Key provisioning process must ensure that only attestation key material that is generated by a valid Endorser is established in Attesters and then configured correctly.
```

pulls.title: Add FIDO biometric authentication as a use case
pulls.author: laurencelundblade
pulls.body:
Address #135.

There are on the order of 1 billion users of biometric authentication

comments.author: dthaler
comments.body:
Discussion: everything you can do, RATS can do better :)  Aka every authentication/access control use case is an attestation use case.  Laurence to take a first shot at adding text into intro above use cases.

Details would be in a doc from FIDO or W3C.

(simplify grammar)
```suggestion
In the Fast IDentity Online (FIDO) protocol, the device in the user’s hand authenticates the human user, whether by biometrics (such as fingerprints), or by PIN and password.
```

Also can we add a citation for the protocol?

Update: changed wording again since PIN/password are not biometrics
So the device is a verifier?  (not sure why "not the relying party" is in the sentence)

```suggestion
For the relying party to know that the authentication is trustworthy, the relying party needs to know that the authenticator part of the device is trustworthy.
```
meaning, for use by the FIDO protocol?  or for use by the FIDO Alliance?
Can we add citations to these protocols if we keep this sentence?
"authenticator" was lower case in 323. Pick one.
Fine with the change. I think that this is *the* most important value add of FIDO: the Authenticator component that can require a human to be in the loop.
The Authenticator is a component of the Attester, isn't it? It is used (in the weakest sense) for evidence generation, I think.

```suggestion
The FIDO protocol employs evidence generation for this. 
```
I know... that is already standard lingo, but I really think that Attestation is too confusing and does not add meaning here.
I do not think hat the Authenticator component alone is the Attester here. It provides strong Authentication to be used in Evidence generated by the device though.

The FIDO protocol does employ attestation. The FIDO protocol defines an attestation protocol of its own. It also can use other attestation protocols.

Conceptually, a FIDO authenticator first runs an attestation protocol to prove itself trustworthy to the relying party (no separation of Verifier and RP in FIDO). Second, it authenticates the user and tells the RP the result. When it is telling the RP the result, it is not running an attestation protocol.

There is an Attester, as formally defined in RATS, within every FIDO Authenticator. A FIDO Authenticator is a superset of an Attester. I don't consider the biometric and the protocol parts that report the biometric result to the RP to be attestation, hence it is a superset.
protocol; addressed in recent commit.
The device verifies biometric input locally. Nothing to do with verifying attestation evidence. Hopefully recent commit addresses this.

I added references for FIDO.

There aren't protocol documents in English for IFAA and WeChat Pay, but there are fluffy marketing overviews. So far citations for the other use cases haven't been required, so this seems OK.

reviews.author: dthaler
reviews.body: Looks pretty good to me now, I think this is a good use case to add.

comments.body:
```suggestion
    author: FIDO Alliance
```
(The copyright at the bottom of the linked URL just says "FIDO Alliance", no "The" in front)

```suggestion
    author: W3C
```
(copyright statement in linked document just says "W3C", with no "The")

```suggestion
For the Relying Party to know that the authentication is trustworthy, the Relying Party needs to know that the Authenticator part of the device is trustworthy.
```

Laurence's explanation makes sense to me, I am fine with "remote attestation" in this sentence (but add "remote").
```suggestion
The FIDO protocol employs remote attestation for this. 
```

```suggestion
The FIDO protocol supports several remote attestation protocols and a mechanism by which new ones can be registered and added. Remote attestation defined by RATS is thus a candidate for use in the FIDO protocol. 
```
Agreed, thanks for checking.

pulls.title: Annotate incomparable timestamps with a clock-specific suffix
pulls.author: dthaler
pulls.body:
Per offline discussion between Henk and Dave, trying this annotation to see if it helps

Also try combining VG and AA into VC since nothing in doc uses AA, and any example could use either VG or AA, so combining makes any example work for both.

Signed-off-by: Dave Thaler <dthaler@ntdev.microsoft.com>

comments.body:
Here is a little weird to me. Because even when the actual time(NSr) > actual time(RXv), 'time(OPr)-time(NSr) < time(RXv)-time(RGv)' may still be true. If so this comparsion makes no sense.
One better expression here, I think, is that 'time(OPr)-time(NSr) + time(RRa)-time(EGa) < time(RXv)-time(RGv)'.

```suggestion
| VG | Value generated             | A value to appear in a Claim was created.  In some cases, a value may have technically existed before an Attester became aware of it but the Attester might have no idea how long it has had that value.  In such a case, the Value generated time is the time at which the Claim containing the copy of the value was created.
```
Less growing pains, more consistency?

The underlying question here is. Is it necessary that some Verifiers are informed about the "timeliness" of the "new VG"?

As Dave already highlighted, we discussed this a bit and the sanity check ask is the following:

If we collapse VG and AA semantics, it is not distinguishable for Verifier, if a corresponding Value generated time is about Attester awareness/Claim generation or Value Generation. Is that okay or does that create uncertainty that could result in degradation of evidence trustworthiness?
Your comment is orthogonal to this PR.  I don't disagree with you, but I think it needn't be in this PR since you're commenting on something is is not changing in this PR.

```suggestion
`time(OPr)-time(NSr) + time(RRa)-time(EGa)< time(RXv)-time(RGv)`.
```

In case others want it combined into this PR, this is William's suggestion that i am ok with.

pulls.title: Revise description of attester<->verifier trust
pulls.author: laurencelundblade
pulls.body:
This adds a paragraph on the primary trust flow to the Attester sub section.  Previously that subsection only discussed secondary trust flow (confidentiality flow)

I'm pretty sure that just about every real attestation use involves the Verifier coming to trust the Attester by receipt of a nonce (or equivalent) signed or authenticated by a key in and protected by the Attester. I don't see how a Verifier can trust an Attester in any other way for just about every attestation use case. I've revised the text to say that.

I think all the discussion about ROM code and HW defenses is now covered in Security Consideration.

The addresses #132

comments.author: henkbirkholz
comments.body:
In general, I find this PR very hard to discuss with its current scope. There seem to be very specific issues with the text that are discussed in this PR right now. And then there seems to be no agreement about if this proposal is deemed useful in general.

Could we please streamline this? (break at any given time, if the answer to a question is no)

1.) Get an agreed upon understanding, if this PR is worthwhile to be addressed
2.) Identify definable issues with the current text this PR modifies and re-issue smaller-scoped PRs

Alternatively, please bash this proposal via your own :-)

"provisioned into it by the Endorser" is not true in general.   For example, it's not true in the case where the Attester is an IoT device that generates its own key pair at the factory, and the public key is then extracted and used to generate a certificate issued by an Endorser (the manufacturer or whoever else), and the certificate itself isn't provisioned on the device but can be looked up on demand by the Verifier.  In this case, there is no "key material" provisioned into the Attester by any entity other than the Attester itself.

Line 723 and 754 are incorrect for the same reason.

```suggestion
The proof is by the signing or authenticating of Evidence (see {{freshness}}).
```
This would need to be a markdown cross reference.
Hard to review since line breaks were removed.  Please revert line breaks.
Keep examples in a separate PR
Yes. Github mistake.

We probably should come up with better phrase -- "establish key material" or "set up key material" or "personalization"? It seems awkward to explain all the options each time it needs to be mentioned.

Even if the key material is generated on the device, you still have to do real work to 1) provide integrity when the public key is coming off the device and 2) make sure you are only taking keys off of real devices (no imposter, forgery or midnight runs). 

I have seen the term "provision" used to mean the whole process at a high level.

I know you keep bringing this up. I very much agree that what you suggest is the best way and should be allowed for and encouraged in the architecture doc, but I also know that are many situations where it can't be done. For example, it can't be done with symmetric keys. It can't be done when you are putting keys into fuses on a chip that has no HW key generation feature. It can't be done when keys are supplied by someone other than the manufacturer.

So it seems we need some term or wording to describe this that covers all the scenarios.

A common problem.

Maybe: "Attesters prove their trustworthiness to Verifiers via their key material that is established in their Attesting Environments under the control and authority of a trusted Endorsers." (might have an effect on the following sentences)

```suggestion

```

```suggestion
Attesters prove their trustworthiness to Verifiers via Evidence signed using key material that is established in their Attesting Environments, and some way of ensuring freshness (see {{freshness}}).
```
Other than line breaks, I agree with the new content.
Need to disambiguate 'root' as it could refer to a root CA or a root of trust component.

It isn't clear which attestation role the operating system vendor is assuming. As an endorser that provisions the attestation private key and the mfg CA that issues the attestation ID certificate, this often isn't an operating system vendor. Since this is an example, the vendor very well could be, but that isn't usually how it works.
Was there consensus that this belongs in the architecture draft?

It is difficult to follow who the subject of the sentence is. If it is the operating system vendor from line 1326 then it doesn't make sense for the OS vendor to know private keys for attesting environments. This draft shouldn't give the impression that it advocates doing that.
I expected the OEM would be in charge of the key creation and certificate issuance since it is a use case where the OEM is 'driving'.
Unclear if root refers to a root CA or root of trust / Attesting Environment.
manufactures - typo?
Is the attestation evidence in the form of an HMAC? Is the Verifier supplying a query to the mfr'r web service in the form of an HMAC and key ID?
This deployment case seems to be 80% overlapping the previous one.

we don't define the term implicit claims (yet) therefore needs some explanation here.
Also need to resolve if "Endorser" can supply "reference values" or if only "Reverence Value Provider" does that.
I assume 'implied claims' are the same as 'implicit claims' and 'static claims'?
presumably the protocol message contains Evidence?
I am not comfortable with using the phrase "non-remote attestation". The reader has no reference or context here and I find it quite confusing.
We should avoid "implied" or "implicit" entirely and find out if "vouched for" suits the text better here.
pls see the comment below

```suggestion
provided about it by the lower-layer firmware or software is true.
```

I think most of the above text applies only to local attestation because of the phrase "implicitly trust firmware..." and no mention of signed evidence.

Since the main subject of this document is remote attestation, I think this paragraph should be move down several paragraphs and clearly prefaced to indicate it is about local attestation that is distinct from the main topic of remote attestation. Perhaps:

> There is also a non-remote attestation use case where the Attester and Verifier are directly connected such that cryptographic proof of trustworthiness is unnecessary (e.g., they are on the same chip).

The sentence about root of trust is an exception as I think it applies to both local and remote attestation.
The anchor for {{security-considerations}} needs to be added.

I would like to add:

> In remote attestation, the Verifier comes to trust the Attester transitively through the Endorser and/or Attester manufacturer.
I think all of the text above is actually about remote (and local, but the main scope is remote) attestation.

```suggestion
and a manufacturer-signed IDevID certificate) secured in the Attester.
```

Is there a citation for "IDevID"?
While that is typical, in some corner cases that would be false, so would only be ok in my opinion if "typically" were added to that suggestion.

While the text refers to HW & SW, as well as elaborates on a specific security considerations unique to a "hardware root of trust", I think it is very much applicable to remote attestation as a whole.

I'd like to see feedback on a specific question, though:

How is a conveyance of data without any "cryptographic proof of trustworthiness" still an attestation procedure at all? "Local" attestation is typically realized via policies that reside in HW roots of trusts. These policies are deployed on an Attester by a trusted party and are semantically close related with the duties of a Verifier, I think (therefore the "local" attestation).

I would simply remove the term "transitively", tbh. Also, the entity here is the manufacturer, which takes on the role of Endorser. I propose to remove the and/or and rephrase as follows:

> In remote attestation procedures, a Verifier comes to trust a Attester with the help of Endorsers. The role of Endorser is often taken on by an Attester's manufacturer.

I did not include the "typical" proposed by Dave here for now. Is that still needed with the new phrasing? While I think so, I also think it would help to understand what Dave means with "n some corner cases that would be false". We might have already elaborated on this, but my memory fails me right now.
I took the liberty and addressed the comment directly in this PR. Please find the added label below.

When there is local trust between the Attester and Verifier it is because they are on the same chip, the same bus or such. The connection between them is trusted without crypto.

The use of the word "implicit" is what makes it local to me. In remote Attestation, the trust is explicit. The Attester manufacturer tells the Verifier it can trust the Attester explicitly.

```suggestion
In most cases, components that have to be vouched for via Endorsements because no Evidence can be created about them are referred to as a roots of trust.
```

```suggestion
In a typical solution, a Verifier comes to trust an Attester
indirectly by having an Endorser (such as a manufacturer) vouch for
the Attester's ability to securely generate Evidence.
In some solutions, a Verifier might be configured to directly
trust an Attester by having the Verifier have the Attester's key
material (rather than the Endorser's) in its trust anchor store.

Such direct trust must first be established at the time of trust anchor
store configuration either by checking with an Endorser at that
time, or by conducting a security analysis of the specific device.
Having the Attester directly in the trust anchor store narrows
the Verifier's trust to only specific devices rather than all devices
the Endorser might vouch for, such as all devices manufactured by the
same manufacturer in the case that the Endorser is a manufacturer.

Such narrowing is often important since physical possession of a device
can also be used to conduct a number of attacks, and so a device in
a physically secure environment (such as one's own premises) may be
considered trusted whereas devices owned by others would not be.
This often results in a desire to either have the owner run their
own Endorser that would only Endorse devices one owns, or to use
Attesters directly in the trust anchor store.   When there are many
Attesters owned, the use of an Endorser becomes more scalable.

```

"by having the Verifier have the Attester's key material"

The Verifier is "made having this key material" by the Endorser role. As a result, in this case the Endorser and Verifier Owner role are probably collapsed?

the Attester's ability to securely generate Evidence.

In some solutions, a Verifier might be configured to directly

Lins 826 just says "key material" not "signing key material".  Pick one and be consistent.

pulls.title: readability rework for use case and terminology sections
pulls.author: SimonFrost-Arm
pulls.body:
Proposed rework of the document flow to address the readability issue raised here: https://github.com/ietf-rats-wg/architecture/issues/163.
Summary of changes: 
Move the 'scene setting' Use Cases section to follow the Introduction
Remove specific terminology (Attester / RP) from the Use Cases section by generalising the language used, while keeping the clarification of those parties
Terminology section now follows Use Case section, which puts it next to the Architecture section, and in particular Fig1, where understanding of the terminology is most needed.
Change alphabetic layout of Terminology section to be more hierarchical on use/importance of terms
Add relationship descriptions between terms.

I know that readability is subjective, but this flow has tested well in local review!

comments.author: mcr

> This PR mixes proposals for two issues, I think.

It seems like two pull requests would be easier for us to come to consensus on.

reviews.author: henkbirkholz
reviews.body:
This PR mixes proposals for two issues, I think.

1.) Moving (and reordering) the Terminology section is of course to be discussed. In comparison, it seems to me the smaller issue addressed. Please mind, that moving the terminology section to the top was an intentional action with the intent to improve readability. The ordering is more a question of style - and if semantic/hierarchic ordering helps, I am all for it.

If your activity of using this document during implementation revealed issues with the order of content sequence, that most definitely has to be taken under consideration.

2.) Changing the layout of use cases as you proposed resonates well with my personal perception. Alas, adding well-defined terms here to help with the mapping to the terminology - therefore straying from the defining principle that use cases deliberately do not use any well-defined words, but colloquial language - was also a conscious decision. I am quite okay with your proposal, as it aligns with the principle of least surprised. But, I can also see the point that early mapping can help. Hence, this also has to be discussed.

Could you please summarize both pieces of your proposal on rats@ietf.org and annotate them with your reasoning to start that discussion?

comments.body: Not sure I like "produce attestation" as a phrase.  First, it would require "attestation" to be defined in a way that is different from any other use in the document.  Second, it also implies that the device (Attester) actually produce something that is consumed by a router (Relying Party), which is not in the case in this architecture... the Attester produces Evidence for consideration by a Verifier, which produces Attestation Results for consideration by Relying Parties.
This PR is problematic in that it starts using capitalized terms like Evidence before being defined

```suggestion
In this case, the device desiring to run an ML model must produce attestation for consideration by a server or service holding ML models it desires to protect
```
Another problem is that this PR deletes the definition of Endorsements from line 178 and doesn't add it back into this terminology section.

I do kind of like the Produces: and Consumes: annotation.  I'd be fine with adding such into the terminology section if others agree.

This PR does make it hard to see changes to the terminology section though, I'd prefer to see a separate PR for such things.
Evidence is briefly defined in the introduction as well as more formally covered in the Terminology section (also Attester and Relying Party).

pulls.title: simple WGLC review suggestions
pulls.author: thomas-fossati
pulls.body:
Coalesce a bunch of small edits suggested in our WGLC review [1]

[1] https://mailarchive.ietf.org/arch/msg/rats/wkPplwedtFDPeCZW9WEq-aqXk7w/

comments.body:
This actually changes the meaning by condensing it to the content of version information about HW and SW (e.g. a Claim about an Attester)

Before it seems to have been version information of the information of the HW and SW (e.g. the Version of an Endorsement of the Claims of an Attester).

Maybe that was unintentional before, but it still seems to be a content change and not an editorial one.
Also a difference. Typical method is "measure then execute", so present seems to be fine. Integrity of code in execution is way more intricate, but maybe was described intentionally here?

```suggestion
: Network equipment such as a router, switch, or access point,
```

Didn't Ira highlight a term that was recommended to be used here? As an intermediate change, I like my proposal better, obviously.
The addition seems warranted to me.

Reads fine to me.

+1

"and so on"

+1

```suggestion
The device illustrated in {{layered}} includes (A) a BIOS stored in read-only memory,
```

Otherwise, fine with me.
Are there irrelevant Claims measured? Are you opening a can of worms here?

One colloquial expression is replacing another colloquial expression here, I think. I ack that "rules that it controls" had a target for removal on its back, but the style of the whole paragraph/section might be the issue here, I think. Not gonna tinker with that here and now, though.

Seems the intend here was to say "this is not always the case when sensitive information is included, but sometimes".

Also, what is sensitive information in the first place? Does sensitive information require extensive integrity protection, because it breaks easily? Seems a tad bit too colloquial to me - not only here, but in the surrounding text.
Text is improved, but I am not really happy with the text in general, as of yet.
+1 grammar

```suggestion
Attestation Results may carry a boolean value indicating compliance or non-compliance with a Verifier's appraisal policy, or may carry a richer set of Claims about the Attester, against which the Relying Party applies its Appraisal Policy for Attestation Results.
```
+1 nice catch
it's not the colloquial flavour that I wanted to fix here, it's the fact that the Verifier _controls_ the rules for PII sharing that seemed wrong.
I agree with this change, since one doesn't think of hardware as "running" per se.

```suggestion
of policies to evaluate the state of the system that is requesting
```
("that" and "which" are generally interchangeable in British English, but in American there is a subtle difference per Chicago Manual of Style.  The RFC Edit pass likes to correct these so pre-emptively doing so here.)

```suggestion
The security of conveyed information may be applied at different layers, whether by a conveyance protocol, or an information encoding format. This architecture expects attestation messages (i.e., Evidence, Attestation Results, Endorsements, Reference Values, and Policies) are end-to-end protected based on the role interaction context.
```

Ack. I'd make it more specific then:

```suggestion
The Verifier might share this information with other authorized parties, according to predefined rules that address the handling of PII (potentially included in Appraisal Policies for Evidence).
```
I am not sure I understand what "version _of_ information" means.  I thought it was a typo.

> Seems the intend here was to say "this is not always the case when sensitive information is included, but sometimes".

I added "typically" below because while this is optional, it makes sense to take some precaution in this specific case.

> Also, what is sensitive information in the first place? Does sensitive information require extensive integrity protection, because it breaks easily? Seems a tad bit too colloquial to me - not only here, but in the surrounding text.

This is in the context of PII handling between mutually trusting parties, which is established by the preceding paragraph.
group agrees that the new text was what was intended.

```suggestion
That is, Attesting Environments collect the values and the information to be represented in Claims, by reading system registers and variables, calling into subsystems, taking measurements on code, memory, or other security related assets of the Target Environment.
```

```suggestion
Only a bootloader with intact integrity will make an appropriate decision. 
Therefore, the Claims relating to the integrity of the bootloader have to be measured securely.
```

```suggestion
Personally Identifiable Information (PII).
```

```suggestion
The Verifier might share this information with other authorized parties, according to a governing policy that address the handling of sensitive information (potentially included in Appraisal Policies for Evidence).
```

```suggestion
Personally Identifiable Information (PII) or system identifiable information.
```

```suggestion
It is assumed that the Attester is located in an isolated environment of a device like a process, a dedicated chip a TEE or such that collects the Claims, formats them and signs them with an Attestation Key. The Attester must be protected from unauthorized modification to ensure it behaves correctly. There must also be confidentiality so that the signing key is not captured and used elsewhere to forge evidence.
```

comments.body: Personally, I find the new text much less clear than the old text

```suggestion
Handles are opaque, non-predictable data regularly broadcast to protocol
```
Also I think "all" is not required.  You could use it with only two.
This is confusing.  Remove it?

```suggestion
The Handle Distributor, hosted in a dedicated entity or co-located with another
RATS role, is trusted by the protocol participants to behave correctly with
```

```suggestion
Handles are opaque, non-predictable data regularly broadcast by a Handle Distributor.  
Each handle represents a specific epoch,
```

```suggestion
        |     Attestation Result                          |
        |-------{H',R{H,time(RX_v)}}------------------>time(RA_r)
```

```suggestion
        |---R{H',R{H,time(RX_v)}}--------------------->time(RA_r)
```

We need a legend. 'R' is short for Attestation Result.

The point of the illustration is that a Conceptual message with a stale handle is conveyed and that the Relying Party can detect that the Handle used in the Conceptual Message -- the relayed Attestation Result -- is not the current handle anymore.

Instead of adding Attestation Result text in the diagram, I simply removed the RR --> which renders the Relayed Attestation Result message a Attestation Message. This probably could be good enough, if the English text than captures that context.

I think that you should leave the text in the diagram fully expanded until we can agree that the new HT math is correct.
Then, let's see if we can find better shortcuts/abbreviations.

Can you please explain where is the confusion?

We think that being able to distinguish between a fully established epoch and one that is still in overlap phase is crucial for a receiver that needs to decide whether to accept or refuse an incoming message.

```suggestion
The following example illustrates a hypothetical Passport Model
solution that uses handles instead of timestamps or nonces.
```
For consistency with the start of examples 1 and 2

The freshness section still calls them nonces in lines 1109-1114. We should be consistent, maybe by calling them handles there.   And these two sentences are not about the example per se, they're about the definition of handles and so I think they should move to where line 1109-1114 are.

I don't think this is true, since the receiver has no idea when time(HT) is.   To avoid race conditions, receivers (Verifiers / Relying Parties) need to accept both the previous handle and the current handle.  In that case, the original text inequalities are correct and this one is not.
I don't understand your point.   If it's in overlap phase, it should still be accepted.
This is either redundant with the first sentence of this section, or everything above here should be moved to the freshness section.
"handle used to generate the handle" is confusing since no such concept was introduced earlier

Problems:
1) the term E is not defined, only Evidence
2) You cannot convey time(VG_a) without synchronized clocks
3) time(EG_a) is left in line 1491 but then not used

1) R is undefined
2) time(RX_v) is not useful to convey without synchronized clocks.  There's nothing the RP can do with it in this section.
time(HT) is not used in any computation or inequality so should be removed for consistency

Sure.  However, in order to be able to _reject_ a message coming from the previous epoch a receiver needs to be able to say: _"overlap is over and the new epoch is now fully established, therefore I will assume whatever comes from a previous epoch is a replay"_

> I don't think this is true, since the receiver has no idea when time(HT) is. 

I see your point, but I wouldn't say it is a false statement.  It is however both imprecise (it should be the worst case delay among all receivers) and not really useful from an operational point of view.  Therefore I'm happy to remove it from the sentence which has clear enough prose to express the idea already.

I think we also need to highlight that the extent of the overlap, the thing previously known as "offset" (would "pad" be a better name?), is a central protocol parameter which needs calibration and agreement among all the participants to be meaningful.  It's not a unilateral decision that a protocol participant makes up by itself.

And another related thing (which I just realised, sorry for overloading the comment) is that the discussion seems to be assuming a network topology where V is _closer_ to the Handle Distributor than A - and therefore V’s epoch starts _before_ A’s epoch.  We should also consider the dual situation and therefore the case where Evidence arrives at V with a handle that V has not yet received.  This calls for extending the “offset” on the left to buffer _maybe valid_ handles?

> [...] the original text inequalities are correct and this one is not

One of the troubles I was having with the original text is that I really don’t understand what the inequality is supposed to say.  In particular, how is `time(HR_v)-time(EG_a)` a definition of “age of the handle used”?  Besides, it seems that there is an unstated assumption here that A and V have synchronised clocks - otherwise time(EG_a) and time(HR_v) are not on the same timeline and can't be meaningfully combined.
I think it should say "the handle [...] used to generate the Evidence is stale" instead?

Accepting an incoming Conceptual Message without overlap phase awareness should be very strongly discouraged, as it can break the whole RATS concept. I understand that it is not obvious or easy for a receiver to infer that it is in an overlap phase. Nevertheless, delimiting factors should be illustrated in this context as best as we can.
Dave took on the task to generate text in the Freshness section that introduces the Handle concept in the body of the document.

It was pointed out to me that my comment was misleading. Unfortunately, I have to agree.

What I intended to convey was: yes, of course the message is accepted, but blindly accepting it without awareness of an overlap phase poses a security risk in the following appraisal procedures due to lack of relevant context information. IHTH
Why couldn't it be collapsed with more than one other RATS role?

```suggestion
Evidence is stale. This indicates that at least one epoch has passed in between,
```
That's a typo. Evidence is correct.

I think the point was to provide more context by using a defined event in the text. I am rather cautious to agree with the notion that "used in a computation or inequality" is a needed requirement here. Also, it is used in a comparison/computation in the text.

We all agree that, for example, illustrating time(HR_a) in the diagram is okay, although it cannot be captured by an Attester with no clock. Consequently, highlighting that time(HT) and time(HR_a) are related to effectively existing overlap phases although the delta is not easy to capture seems fine to me.

1.) As far as I understand it, this seems to be a proposal simplify the layout of the diagram.

The current state evolved into a representation that was neither readable nor compressible:
  
```
     time(EG_a)
        |----Evidence{time(EG_a)}
        | {Handle1,time(EG_a)-time(VG_a)}
```
Whatever the solution in the end, this has to be fixed, I think (the { vs ( syntax is never introduced and not intuitive).

2. true, we have to walk through the sequence again together, I think

3. It still happens. Is it okay to not illustrates what happens, but is not conveyed in a Conceptual Message? I have some doubts that "used" only is restricted to conveyance or am I missing something obvious here?

First of all, you intended to write "where V is _closer_ to the Handle Distributor than A", I think.

Additionally, I think we came to the conclusion that it is preferable to use an event (defined in the table) in the text of the Appendix in order to provide better context. Simply removing the sentence with time(HT) at the end would go against that. Hence, I would recommend to not simply remove it, but to replace it with a paragraph that highlights why event types, such as time(HT), that can frame the extent of an overlap phase are vital to readers of the document here.

In general, Handle Distribution is in support of various scenarios. In some of them the receivers have no clocks at all, in some of them only a few - e.g. the Verifier. Maybe it would help with the scenario description, if we add a Clock to the Verfier? (so that only the swarm of Attesters has no clock)

> First of all, you intended to write "where V is _closer_ to the Handle Distributor than A", I think.

Your thinking is correct, fixed.  Thanks for spotting it!

> Additionally, I think we came to the conclusion that it is preferable to use an event (defined in the table) in the text of the Appendix in order to provide better context. Simply removing the sentence with time(HT) at the end would go against that. Hence, I would recommend to not simply remove it, but to replace it with a paragraph that highlights why event types, such as time(HT), that can frame the extent of an overlap phase are vital to readers of the document here.

I agree.  Frankly, I care more about clarity at the conceptual level rather than anything else.  So, whatever device helps to better grasp the ideas is very welcome.

> In general, Handle Distribution is in support of various scenarios. In some of them the receivers have no clocks at all, in some of them only a few - e.g. the Verifier. Maybe it would help with the scenario description, if we add a Clock to the Verfier? (so that only the swarm of Attesters has no clock)

What I was trying to say is just that the second inequality makes no sense because the two `time()` functions apply to different timelines (and are therefore the comparison is between pears and apples!) unless the underlying clocks at V and A are synchronised.  If we cannot assume the presence of clocks at nodes implementing the A role, let alone synchronised clocks, well that's another good reason for dropping the inequality, isn't it?

If instead there is at least some assumption on clock presence in some of the roles (and possibly a synchronisation requirement?), that should be clearly stated.
"... co-located with other RATS roles, is trusted..."
The word 'while' can be removed or changed to "but" or "however"

I agree there should be a legend. 
However, these examples are very complex and very terse for an architecture document. It would be better IMO to number each message in the sequence diagram flows then explain them in more readable detail in a numbered prose section below the diagram.
Recommend rebasing on top of PR #257

It actually doesn't matter whether it's "broadcast" or only unicast to two specific entities (e.g., an Attester and Verifier) that use it.
```suggestion
At `time(HT)`, the Handle Distributor sends handle `H` which starts a new
```
`E` in line 1492 is Evidence whereas here it's Epoch, which is confusing.   I'd like to fix line 1492 to not abbreviate Evidence
which line is "definition provided above" referring to?

and what happens if the Relying Party hasn't gotten H' yet?   (I added a brief discussion of this in PR 257, so would be good to clarify here.  This section just has an example so any answer may be ok.)
I agree that illustrating time(HR_a) in the diagram is okay so long as it's used in a message or computation/inequality.

In the snippet in Henk's comment there's two {} blocks on the same message, which should never happen.
{} means "includes (inside)".  That is Evidence{time(EG_a)} means that time(EG_a) is inside the signed Evidence.   I completely agree it would be good to explain the notation before or in the first example where it's used.

```suggestion
The example in {{fig-handle-passport}} illustrates a hypothetical Passport Model
solution that uses handles instead of nonces or timestamps.
```
Keep wording consistent with intros to the previous sections.

I'd recommend referencing the "Implicit Timekeeping using Epoch Handles" subsection rather than the full "Freshness" section.  And "according to the definition provided" there is ambiguous since it mentions that any solution has to take one of three approaches, so need to clarify which approach is shown in this example.

I.e., quoting text there:
> An actual solution also needs to take into account race conditions
> when transitioning to a new epoch, such as by using a counter signed
> by the Handle Distributor as the handle, or by including both the current and
> previous handles in messages and/or checks, by requiring retries
> in case of mismatching handles, or by buffering incoming messages
> that might be associated with a handle that the receiver has not yet
> obtained.

time(VG_a) makes no sense in this example since clocks are not synchronized so the actual value is meaningless, and there's no other time(foo_a) transmitted to the attester to use as a delta.
The old (red) text had time(EG_a)-time(VG_a) which did make sense, as the delta is meaningful to the receiver (it just requires a clock in the Attester that need not be synchronized).

That's why the old text had time(RX_v)-time(RG_v) is is meaningful.
time(RX_v) is useless in this message for the same reason as in my previous comment.

Implementers need to pay close attention to the protection of the Attester and the factory processes for provisioning the Attestation key material. If either of these are compromised, the remote attestation becomes worthless because an attacker can forge Evidence.
```

Implementers need to pay close attention to the protection of the Attester and the factory processes for provisioning the Attestation key material. ```

If my understanding is correct, a TPM is not an Attesting Environment as defined in lines 400-401, they are a piece of an Attesting Environment. There is no limit to or requirement on the types of hardware or software environments that can be used to implement an Attesting Environment, for example: Trusted Execution Environments (TEEs), embedded Secure Elements

reviews.body: I prefer that each sentence start on a newline as it makes git diffs easier.

comments.body:
```suggestion
The root layer of an Attester includes at least one root of trust.
```

```suggestion
In order to appraise Evidence generated by an Attester, the Verifier needs to trust the Attester's root of trust.
```

"Claims can be collected from or about each layer, including roots of trust."

This is technically correct. On the glossary level we have the responsibility to make absolutely sure that the reader is aware that a root of trust cannot ever generate Evidence from Claims about itself.
Normally, claims are not self-asserted by a layer or root of trust.

```suggestion
Claims can be collected from or about each layer.

comments.author: henkbirkholz
comments.body:
In general, I like the re-introduction of the "timekeeping" subsections a lot.

+1

```suggestion
Evidence or Attestation Results against the latest handle it received from
```

```suggestion
requiring a reliable clock or time synchronization in order to generate or
```
I am not sure I understand what we mean by "epoch counter" and how is it supposed to work.

```suggestion
previous handles in messages and/or checks, by requiring retries
in case of mismatching handles, or by buffering incoming messages
that might be associated with a handle that the receiver has not yet
obtained.
```
The discussion around races should state the fact that the fundamental factor at play is the accurate estimation of the end-to-end delay of the communication channel.

```suggestion
Handles are different from timestamps as they do not have to convey information about a point in time, i.e., they are not necessarily monotonically increasing integers.
```
"obtained" or "received"?

An epoch counter is (sometimes persistent) state on an entity receiving handles that basically retains n handles in, for example, a ring buffer and therefore provides a record of the past n handles in sequence.
While non-trivial to capture by a single entity involved, this is crucial to understand the overlap phase "in a bigger picture" and how to conduct appraisal procedures later on, I think.
Disagree, the prop delay is irrelevant in all of my text, and no estimation is needed.
Ok
Obtained sounds better ("receiver received" sounds odd to me).  Thomas's text looks ok to me.

Updated text per Thomas's comment.   If the handle is a signed counter, and the handle is sent in (say) evidence, then the verifier receiving it that hasn't seen the new handle yet can simply accept it if it's signed by the HD it trusts and it sees the counter is higher than the handle it has.

```suggestion
Three ways in which the process fail are as follows.

```suggestion
Three ways in which the process may fail include: 

* First, the Verifier may not issue a positive Attestation Result due to the Evidence not passing the Appraisal Policy for Evidence.

* The second way in which the process may fail is when the Attestation Result is examined by the Relying Party, and based upon the Appraisal Policy for Attestation Results, the result does not pass the policy.

pulls.title: Fix layered attestation diagram
pulls.author: dthaler
pulls.body:
Once we added Reference Value Provider as a role, the diagram wasn't updated.  The "A, B, and C" part is about reference values, not the endorsing of signing capabilities, which is just about A.

Signed-off-by: Dave Thaler <dthaler@ntdev.microsoft.com>

reviews.author: nedmsmith
reviews.body: requesting adding ", b and c" to the endorsements portion of the figure.

comments.body: I think it is correct to include "Endorsement for A, B and C" since it is possible that attestation keys could exist at other layers besides the first (A). The definition of endorsement focuses on the "signing capability" which doesn't have to be centralized into a single part of the device / platform.

Endorsement is defined as "A secure statement that an Endorser vouches for the integrity of an Attester's various capabilities such as Claims collection and Evidence signing."   A is what vouches for the integrity of B's capabilities and similarly B is what vouches for C.

We have no discussion anywhere of having multiple components vouch for the same target environment, so I disagree with Ned's proposal as being insufficiently motivated by any other text.  This PR is just to make the doc be internally consistent and fix an accidental oversight when RV providers were added distinct from Endorsers.

I agree that the diagram requires 'fixing' from the change made earlier. 
I disagree that that attesting environment A is effectively the Endorser for environment B and so on. While it is correct that A 'vouches' for B and B for C etc... I disagree that A can vouch for the signing capability of B beyond what is captured in software. Software has to run on hardware that A isn't capable of assessing. If B and C are not hardware (only A) then I agree with Dave's analysis. If B and C can be hardware (that isn't A hardware) then it is possible for B and C to also have Endorsers.

The text says:
> The device illustrated in {{layered}} includes (A) a BIOS stored in read-only memory,
> (B) an operating system kernel, and (C) an application or workload.

So B and C are already explicitly stated to be software per above.

comments.body:
```suggestion
Without a specific proposal to compare against, it is impossible to know if the security considerations listed below have been mitigated well.
```
1) Fix double "the". 
2) Re "considerations ... mitigated":  you mitigate threats... are all security considerations threats?
3) some considerations aren't part of the implementation per se, like the discussion of physical security at a factory.  Would you consider those part of "a specific proposal"?
Is physical security at a factory part of an "implementation"?

```suggestion
Without a specific proposal to compare against, it is impossible to know if the security threats listed below have been mitigated well.
```

```suggestion
The security considerations below should be read as being essentially requirements against realizations of the RATS Architecture.
Some threats apply to protocols, some are against implementations (code), and some threats are against physical infrastructure (such as factories). 
```

pulls.title: two additional typos found by SecDir review
pulls.author: mcr
pulls.body: close #430

comments.body:
My reading of https://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/comprise is that this change is not grammatically correct.  It was ok as it was, but more readable would be
```suggestion
Measurements that have been signed by such components are comprised of Evidence that when evaluated either supports or refutes a claim of trustworthiness.
```
That is, "of" is used with "are comprised" but not "comprise".
lets add Dave's two words to be both readable and correct

pulls.title: Stupid typo
pulls.author: hannestschofenig
pulls.body: You want to say "Certification Authority" not "Certificate Authority"

comments.body:
I Googled "CA" and found many uses of Certificate Authority. But I looked at RFC 4949 and found it recommends using Certification Authority.

~~~~
$ certificate authority
   (D) Synonym for "certification authority".

   Deprecated Term: IDOCs SHOULD NOT use this term; it suggests
   careless use of the term "certification authority", which is
   preferred in PKI standards (e.g., [X509, R3280]).
~~~~

reviews.author: henkbirkholz
reviews.body: yeah. thanks for catching that!
